editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A PLAY: As it is Acted at the Theatre Royal, By their Majesties Servants.
LONDON, Printed for R. Bentley in Russel-street in Covent-Garden; and I. Hindmarsh at the Golden Ball in Cornwell, over against the Royal Exchange. 1686.

div.head: To the truly Noble and Illustrious Prince CHRISTOPHER Duke of ALBEMARLE, Earl of Torrington, Barron Monck of Potheridge, Beauchamp, and Teyes, Knight of the most Noble Order of the Garter: And one of the Lords of his Majesty's most Honourable Privy Council, &c.
div.p:
I HAD not presum'd to trouble you with the reading this Trifle, had I not bin proud of an Occasion of Dedicating my self, as well as it, to your service: Scribles of this Nature are usually design'd only to insinuate the Author into the good Opinion of his Patron; but besides that, my Lord, I must confess another meaning, and acknowledge this Minute my happiest, since it gives me an Opportunity of prostrating my self, and Book, at the Feet of a true, Loyal English Nobleman, whose Virtues Lineally descended, have justly received no blemish; One who may, like the Heroes of Old, suffer depressions through the want of Iustice, from byass'd or mistaken Opinions; but never through want of Merit. Besides my own humble Acknowledgements, my Lord, for the favours I have particularly received from your Grace; I think it is my Duty, and indeed the Duty of every good Subject, as well as my self, with Tears of Ioy, to thank you for your late Loyalty,
Dil ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ence, and unwearied service of the King, against the Rebels; in which you faithfully shew'd the unvalued Vertue of your Temper, sparing no Cost, nor ommitting no Stratagem, that could advance to the eternal fixing our Great (tho' then scarce settl'd) Monarch in this Throne; as once your Immortal, and I hope (never forgotten) Father, did the late glorious Prince before. We cannot now doubt, but that Almighty Providence has pronounced a long and happy Reign to our Great and Glorious Master; his late wonderful, as well as fortunate success, sufficiently shews the Eternal Arm was lifted for him, in the Miraculous and speedy scattering and confounding so formidable an Eenmy, as the Rebels were, or wou'd have bin, upon the least fleshing and encouragement. Nor shall we ever, I hope, forget your Graces Indefatigable Zeal, Policy and Diligence, in defending and keeping a City, which they so vehemently aim'd at, as highly conducing to their Designs; this was a Piece of Service, which (without offence to any one) I hope I may presume to say, none but the Son of a Restorer could have done, the Brood of Rankest Rebellion, like the Plague, having reign'd there long before; and the Mobile being all poison'd with the pernitious Tenets of a misled, ungrateful Vsurper; who some years since took his Progress that way, to prepare the Party for this purpose. This, Sir, your very Enemies (if it is possible you can have any) must acknowledge: Nor can I omit the Conflicts of your Graces vexation, and dissatisfaction, by being disappointed
of ingaging the Enemy, as you heartily wish'd, and endeavour'd to do: I know the Noble Old General's Genius inspir'd ye; and your Martial Spirit even burnt with the Lust of Action; you might well be said in this juncture, to be tortur'd with as much rage for not fighting, and Conquering, as a Masterly Poet has written of your Glorious Father, when in the late Dutch War Ingaging almost a whole Fleet, he was disabled by Du Ruyter.
Ruyter he spies, and full of Martial heat,
Tho' half the Number, thinks the Odds too great;
And swoln with Sense of former Glory won,
Thought Monk must be by Albemarle out-done
And at last describing the Fight, and the General's Rage for the ill success, he goes on,
Not Virtuous Men, unworthily abus'd;
Not constant Lover, without Cause refus'd:
Not honest Merchant broke, nor skilful Player
Hiss'd off the Stage, nor sinners in despair;
Not Parents mock'd, not Favourites disgrac'd,
Not Rump by Monk or Oliver displac'd;
Not Kings depos'd, nor Prelates e're they dye,
Feel half the rage of Generals when they flye.

This, tho' on a Contrary Theam, I am sure is not Improperly adapted; your inward and secret disturbance
for being depriv'd of the Glory you hop'd for, being rightly considered, was not less, than that of your Noble Father.

And now, my Lord, for fear of troubling your Grace with two prolix an Epistle, which cannot excuse my fault, for the meanness of what I present ye, I must make use of the Confidence, natural to Poets; and briefly beg to shelter my self under your Graces Patronage; whose true Vertue, and uncommon Sweetness, in favouring Wit and Merit, where-ever you find it, emboldens me to expect a favourable reception, in hopes, that the true English Noble Temper, which influences all Mankind with Admiration, that have the Honour to know you, will not fail to bless particularly with your good Opinion, and pardon the Errors, and Presumption of,

closer.signed: Your Graces most devoted, Humble Honourer, and Obedient Servant, T. D'URFEY.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: Du Pier, his Lieutenant. Mr. Griffin.
Boldsprite, The Ships Master. Mr. Percival.

item.label: Three wild Fellows of the Town, that Ramble to Sea, and desert their Wives.

list.item: Surgeon of the Ship. Mr. Sanders.
Don Sebastian. Governour of several Portuguize Islands, but chas'd form thence by French Pyrates. Mr. Gillow.
La Mure. A Vilainous French Pyrate. Mr. Norris.
Bourcher. His Companion, and Friend. Mr. Harris.

list.head: Women.
list.item: Roselia. Protectress of the Amazonian Countrey. Mrs. Cory.
Clarinda. Her Eldest Daughter. Lady Slingsby.
Aminta. Her youngest Daughter, ravish'd from her by La Mure, in her Infancy, and bred up with him. Mrs. Cook.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.stage: Spoken by Mr. HAINS with a Western Scyth in his Hand.
div.l: FROM the West, as Champion in defence of Wit,
I come, to mow you Critticks of the Pit,
Who think we've not improv'd what Fletcher Writ.
This Godly Weapon first invented was
By Whigs, to cut down Monarchy like Grass;
But I know better how to use these Tools,
And have reserv'd my Scythe to mow down Fools:
Yet o' my Conscience they wou'd sprout again,
And the Herculean Labour were in vain.
The Pit, like Hydra's, still wou'd yield supplies,
From one lop't Block-head, twenty more would rise.
A sort of City Critticks yonder sit,
For this destroying Engine not unfit,
Cuckolds were always Enemies to Wit;
For Wit oft draws the Wife to leave her Spouse,
To take a small refreshing at our House.
Phantastick Tastes how hard it is to please!
Critticks, like Flyes, have several Species.
There's one that just has paid his grutch'd half-Crown,
Cries, Rot the Play, Pox on't, let's cry it down.
The censuring Spark wou'd fain seem Great and Witty,
Yet Whispers Politicks with Orange Betty;
She cracks his Philberds, whilst he, in her Ear,
Is Fighting o're again the Western War,
Bragging what numbers his sole Arm has kill'd,
Tho' the vain Fop perhaps was ne're i'th' Field.
Thus Worm that snugs in Shell where it was bred,
Is nothing to the Maggot in his head,
For Harmless Insect that those Nuts create
Is nothing to the Maggot of the Pate,
Now such a Fop as this wou'd I be at.
Another to compleat his daily Task,
Fluster'd with Claret, seizes on a Mask,
Hisses the Play, steals off with Punk i'th' dark,
He Damns' the Poet, but she Claps the Spark.
I wonder if the Law cou'd doom one dead,
That now should lop off such a Fellow's Head!
It cannot be found Murther.‚ÄîAnd to share
This dreadful Fate, You Critticks all prepare.
For besides all my Scythians yet unseen,
We've yet a Female Common-wealth within,
Who strongly Arm'd, like Furies venture on,
And if y'approach their Trenches once, y'are gone.

div.head: ACT I. SENE I. Covent-Garden.
div.stage: Enter Marine at one Door, Aminta mask'd at another.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: MY Love!

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: I hope I am.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Most certain; so punctual, and so fair, it must be she!

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Punctual, you have reason to own me, for if you knew the Difficulty I have undergone, to get out to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I can guess at it, and am too sensible of the Villany of that French-firework, thy Damn'd Guardian, not to know the Difficulty. But 'prithee tell me, what pretty Stratagem did Love instruct thee with, to make me thus happy?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: After Dinner, 'tis always his Custom to call for Tea, in which I cunningly infus'd a Dram or two of Opium, which made its Operation instantly; for after sneezing two or three times, and according to his usual manner, fetching a Rhumatick Cough from the bottom of his Lungs, which I always pray heartily may choak him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And so do I too, Faith. I hope our prayers will be heard one Day.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: He fell fast asleep, and by that means gave me Opportunity to meet an ungrateful Creature here, that is more ready to laugh at me for my Weakness, than reward me for my Love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What a barbarous thought is that! Deny it, and make me amends, or I swear I will kiss thee into an Extasie.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Oh! I am fond and foolish: All my Actions shew Woman, silly Woman, and must confess, deserve it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Prithee, no more of this, it wrongs my Love. And since we have leasure to talk an Hour, make me so happy to hear the remainder of thy Story; the story of thy Father, and the manner of thy bringing hither to England, under the Tuition of that Villain, that Cursed Pirate La Mure: You have often begun it, but we have bin still interrupted.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: 'Tis a sad Tale; but I can deny you nothing: If you remember then, I told you that Don Sebastian was my Father. A generous Portuguise; of Noble House, and Nature; and Governour of several large Plantations in the Happy Islands; his Industry and Care made him so rich, that he might vie with Princes; so stor'd he was with Friends and Gifts of Fortune! But many years he had not thus continued, when Hell contriving how to blast our Joys; drove on our Shore a number of French Pyrates; of which La Mure was the most Villainous, and being Captain of the rest, and well stor'd with Ammunition, enter'd upon our Fortress, ruin'd our Plantations; and chas'd the Peaceful Industrious Portugals, like Flocks of Sheep upon the barren Mountains.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Inhumane Villains!

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: My Father, in this distress, willing to save his Treasure, with the help of my Brother, and a Party of Negro Slaves, secretly Convey'd his Plate, Money, and Jewels into a small Vessel, and put to Sea, with design-to return, when they were gone, and comfort us with his Fortune and Policy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The Design was prudent, whatever the Event was.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Oh it was fatal! For this Curst La Mure having Intelligence by his Spies of my Fathers escape, and not knowing how to pursue him, turn'd his rage upon my poor Mother, my Sister, and my self. And having Laden his Ship with the Spoils and Riches of our Island, carried us with him, and the put to Sea.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Where will this end?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: You shall know instantly. And the greatest Barbarity that ever Villain acted: For sailing thence a few Leagues, and resolving to be revenged on us, for the loss of my Father's Treasure, he leaves my sighing Mother and a little Sister alone and comfortless upon a wild and barren Island.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Damn'd Hellish Dog!

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p:
And since that hour, I never heard of 'em. As to my self, (tho' an Infant,) it pleas'd his Devil-ship to like my face. And therefore brought me, (with my Nurse, who has since told me this Story;) with him to London; where I have liv'd a melancholly and hated
Life ever since: And now am hourly plagu'd with the intollerable Harangues of his Nauseous Love, and Impertinent Follies. Oh Marine!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why sighs, my dearest?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'le tell thee, and charge thee by thy Love,
Nay, by thy Soul, and its divinest Virtue,
To perform my Injunction.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Can I with Honour do it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, else I would nor propose it.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Speak then, nay quickly, for I fear he'll wake e're I get back agen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This coming night,
When the Tell-tale Clock has told its midnight story,
And sleep Charms all but Libertines and Lovers,
Steal from his House, and fall into my Arms;
I have a Ship lies ready in the Port,
Laden and fit to sail, the wind stands fair too,
In her I'le place my Love, and free her from
The hated bondage of her Cursed Jaylor.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Oh! I shall ne're endure the Sea agen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Rather endure a Storm in all its frights and dangers, than live to be enslav'd to Villany.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: But if you shou'd forsake me! Oh misery!
And leave me helpless on some blasted Countrey,
As he once did my Mother!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yet more doubts: by all that's good, you wrong me; prithee no more of it. Come, your Promise?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: I do: I must.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: At twelve.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Till then farewell. Heaven and its Angels guard thee.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Oh Love! thou mak'st us do we know not what.

div.stage: [Leads her to the Door. Ex Amint.
Enter Du Piere, (his Sword drawn) Bold-Sprite after him.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Nay prithee Lieutenant, get off further; Life, I am affraid the Fellow is kill'd.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Kill'd! Hang him; no Sword can hurt him; His Soul and all his Spirits are shrunk so low into his heels. 'Tis impossible any wound given him should be Mortal. A Slave, to abuse our noble Admiral. By this Hilt, if thou hadst not stood in my way, I would have cut the Rogue into Stakes, and have eaten him up for my Breakfast.

sp.speaker: Marin.
sp.p: How now, Lieutenant, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Captain, your Humble Servant. I Plague on't, I know not, a damn'd huffing fellow yonder, a Rebel, Whiggy Buffle head‚ÄîI know not what to make of him, not I‚Äîhad the Impudence, to my Face, to affront our great Master the Admiral.

sp.speaker: Marin.
sp.p: And thou hast kill'd him, I warrant.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Clapt him through the Guts‚ÄîHam-string'd him; broke out six or seven of his Teeth with the Pummel of my Sword, or so: But I'le be pox'd, if he does not live to be hang'd, for all this.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Prithee, do not thou tempt thy Fate, and live to be hang'd instead of him: Our City Juries will shew thee but little favour or affection, if thou once com'st into their Clutches.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Consume 'em: I'le sooner make my self Immortal, with a pennyworth of Rats-bane, than stand to the Courtesie of such a Cry of Blood-hounds. But prithee, Captain, when shall we to Sea agen? Pox o', this Dirty part of the World, a Man only fowls his Linnen here, and draws Air amongst a rout of Rebels‚ÄîI am clearly for the Watry Element: And had rather Converse with Dolphins, Whales, and Porpices, than our Natives: Why, they are honest Creatures, and better Company.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: They are so i'faith: And thou shalt be with them suddenly. For I have some urgent business will call me aboard within these few hours. And to morrow, if the Wind sit fare, adieu old England.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: By the green Neptune, I am glad on't: A Brummingham Son of a Whore, affront the Noble Admiral! Nay, 'tis well they scour'd, we should have made a separation between some of their Souls and Bodies else before this time, hah, Master!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What, has my Master bin in the Skirmish too?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Yes Faith, the old Lad was all hands aloft with 'em. I saw him clap one of 'em thro' the Shoulder, and throw a couple more into the Cellar; that I saw him do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, well said old Sea-mark.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Me! Why, how now, d'ee doubt me? Give me but a good Cause, and a good Sword, and if I flinch, hang me on the Top-Mast-head, or flea me, and make Ship-Buckets of my Hide. What, I have not had so many Towels drawn through me for nothing, sure!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. But hark you, Lieutenant, a word with thee; I must require thy assistance in a business to night.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Require‚ÄîCommand, dear Captain! Pox of requirings and requests‚Äîyour Ear‚Äîis there a Man or a Woman in the Case?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: A Woman, Du Piere! an Angel-Woman! a Fortune too, and Young as the Rose-bud‚ÄîBeautiful as the Blushing Morning; and as willing as my self.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Good. Well, must we scale for her, or steal her Cunningly? Must we mount the Counterscarp like Men of Mettle; or squeeze our selves, like Cats, into the Cellar Window?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Neither; she will meet us half way.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Gad, a Gentlewoman I warrant her: Is there no one else but her to take care of?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, Faith yes, there may a Man come into her rescue, which if it happen, I must enjoyn thee to‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Cut his Throat‚ÄîHumh.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, no: onely oppose him, whilst I get off with my fair Prize.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
Mar.
sp.p: But what shall we do for a third Man, in case of Danger? who, amongst the Ships Crew, can we trust in such a business?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Why, Old Tarr there, against the World: There was not such another for a Wench, since Noah's Flood.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Captain, if you dare trust me in your Affair, they shall saw off my Beard with a Back-Sword, e're I leave you: Tho' I care not this for the Woman‚Äîfor my part, I am past these things.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, well, my good Friend, I will be oblig'd to thee. Go then instantly and prepare the Barge, and meet me at Eleven, here at the Corner of the Piazza.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: The Wind favours our Design rarely too; besides, we shall have more Company, for there are three or four young Blades, Acquaintance of mine, that it seems are married to ill Wives, and to avoid 'em, design to take a Ramble, and go Reformades with us; for I told 'em it could not be long before we should put to Sea; and since it happens thus opportunely‚ÄîI'le send instantly to give 'em notice.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Do‚Äîif they are of the Town-breed, they may prove very good Diversion for us.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: The best in the World, Faith, I know 'em to a Hair‚ÄîThey supt to night at the Rose, and I believe are there still, for they are no Starters, to my knowledge‚ÄîI'le step into your Lodging, since 'tis so near hand, and write a Letter to 'em to be ready.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'le go with thee, and prepare all things for our Adventure‚ÄîAh, Lieutenant! This Fortune-stealing is a blessed business, is it not?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Ah, if she were but old, tough, and stanch! Pox on't, I hate your young Weehees, Skitish Colts‚Äîthey are so hard mouth'd, there's no dealing with 'em.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I hope to see thee fitted one day: Come, Let's away,‚Äî

div.head: SCENE, A Tavern.
div.stage: Enter Franvile, Frugal, and Hazard, at a Table with two Lights.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: ARe we all agreed then?

sp.speaker: Frug. Haz.
sp.p: All, all! most Constantly.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let's hear the Oath once more. Come, Frugal‚Äîmy Merchant Royal; thou shalt be Speaker. Silence.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: First we have sworn to take a Ramble to Sea for three years, and during that Term, we have oblig'd our selves never to converse with our Wives, kiss our Wives, nor remember our Wives.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, nor Children, but let them stay at home, keep Lent, and chew the Cud.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: And to this we all once more swear.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: All, all.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Kiss the Book.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: But harkee, Gentlemen, now I have sworn this, 'tis fit I should know the meaning on't‚Äî'Tis but just we declare some Reasons why we leave our Wives,‚Äîhah?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis so: Let one speak then, and the other two shall be Judges.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Do you begin then.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: With all my Heart: Why, first then, most Judicious Auditors, the Reason why I desert my Matrimony is, because she grudges me my Dress, and Garniture, and takes more care to Lace her own Petticoat, than my Pantaloons. Besides, she knows that Dress and Garniture, as I said before, are the only Comforts of my Life: I should lead the life of a Dog, if it were not for my Feathers, my Fiddles, and my Fineries: But I'le be reveng'd for her, for I have prepar'd a Wardrobe, that shall outshine the Sun in the new World, where we are going. And resolve to bid adien to my damn'd Dog with a Bottle at home: What say you now? Have I not Reason?

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Reason! reason! great reason.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Reason! reason! great reason.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Come, now Merchant‚Äînow, let's here thine?

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Mine! nay, if I have not Reason, the Devil's in't! Mine! why, look ye, In the first place, Gentlemen, you must know that I am a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: My Wife is an eternal Scold, and had two By-blows before I marry'd her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hem! Let's have no more on't; Tace! thou hast very Substantial Reason, Faith.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Most Powerful! there's great strength of Reason in't.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: I think so. Besides, she was lavish and extravagant, and continually rail'd at my Usury, and honest turning the penny: but to be reveng'd on her, I cunningly broke lately, have put all my Plate, Money, and Jewels into two Chests, and intend to seek some other Countrey; where I will live, grow rich, and plant a Colony. Now your approbations, Gentlemen? Have I not Reason?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ay; the Deme take me, if thou hast not. But come Sharper, now for thee. What occasion hadst thou to leave thy Wife?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Oh! occcasion enough, Faith.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: What, prithee?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Because I could not keep her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pithy and short.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: A very solid Reason in troth, and must pass muster.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Besides, I have had an Antipathy to Woman-kind, ever since I saw one of 'em unscrue her Nose one night‚ÄîOh, that Nose! that Nose has stuck in my Stomach plaguily.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hell. I see we are all fixt, and of one mind: And resolve to forget and despise that Vexatious and Impertinent Sex. For my own part, I hate a Woman heartily.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: And all things with flat. Bottoms I abominate.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Sir, here's a Letter just now left at our House, directed to you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: News, news, my Lads! rare news!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: What, prithee?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The Captain's just a going; the Ship is fall'n down, and the Barge given order for: here's a Letter from the Lieutenant, that says, they'l be gone by four a Clock this morning. I'le e'en go instantly and get ready my Money and Wardrobe: And then adieu dear Dog with a Bottle, as I said before.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: And I my Chests of Plate and Jewels.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: And I my Cat, and my Bale of Dice: For that's all my Cargo.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come away, Boys; make haste, we shall lose the wind else.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: I'le be ready in a moment.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: If I can but draw 'em in to play in the new World, where we are a going‚ÄîI am made for ever. Well, Fortune for me, there lyes all my hopes.

div.head: SCENE, Covent-Garden.
div.stage: Enter Marine, Du Piere and Boldsprite.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: DOst thou see that Light in the Window there?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Yes, I thank my Fortune, I have been acquainted with such Stars before now: And on these Occasions two: But I had rather that Meteor were extinguisht for all that, Captain, left we should be seen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis past twelve, and few people pass this way.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: I fancy your Fortune-stealer to be very like your Venison-stealer, that thinks himself oblig'd to the Moon, till he has got his Game, but afterwards wishes her in a dark-Lanthorn, for fear it should be taken from him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Master, be sure you scout diligently, and tell us if any one comes.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Go too, go too, mind your Business, and make haste; 'tis well there's Money in the Case. Before I would stand quaking here for a squab-sucking Rabbit; that's hardly worth the skinning, I'd as soon stand Sentinel upon one of the Moles at Argier, tho' I were sure of neither Pay, nor Provender.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Hark! What noise was that? Didst hear no noise?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Some body at prayers, I think: Pox on't, we shall have ill luck.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: 'Tis some dreaming Phanatick or other is singing of Psalms in's sleep.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Come, Captain, prithee give the Sign. I long to have the Treasure in our Custody: That if any resistance happens, we may fight for something.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This must be the Door. Harkee, Lieutenant, prithee look to that corner of the Street‚ÄîI think I hear the Constable and Watch.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: No. Rot 'em, they are making themselves drunk with Brandy. They'l ne'er mind us. Come, come, the sign, the sign.

div.stage: Enter Aminta with a Candle and Casket above.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: What's that there in white?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Hush, it must be she.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: In her Smock, I hope: To make a quicker dispatch of the Business.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Are you alone? What's that yonder?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Two worthy Friends, that I've intrusted to assist me.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Oh my my Love: How shall I get to thee? For this jealous Wretch has taken the Key of the Street door into his Chamber.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Leap into my Arms, I can bear thy weight with ease.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: 'Sbud, would I had her weight in Tobacco or Pepper. Why, what a bustle's here with a green Artichoak?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: No‚ÄîI must venture to get it from thence: In the mean time, catch this Casket; keep it diligently; for 'tis worth your Care: whil'st I go and try my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Make haste, my Dearest: For I am impatient, till I have thee in my Arms. Lieutenant!

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: How now? What has Heav'n sent us?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: There's something in this Casket, Lieutenant, that will pay for our trouble.

sp.speaker: D. Pier
sp.p: Why, merry be her Heart: I like a Wench that pays well for her Man, before she has him: And of all Mistresses, your giving Mistress ought most to be admir'd.

div.stage: [A noise of breaking a Looking-glass within.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Heark, what's that?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Mischief! I'le lay my Life: The Truce is broken, and War will ensue. Tarr, hawl up thy Main Sheet, there's a Storm a coming.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Oh, undone, undone! ruin'd for ever!

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: I thought so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What's the matter, Sweet! Fear nothing. Thou art safe as in a Castle here.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Eagerly reaching the Key out of the Window, my Sleeve hitcht in the great Looking-glass, pull'd it after me, and broke it in pieces: Which has, I am sure, alarm'd the House. Hark‚ÄîI hear 'em coming.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Well, well, and let 'em come. Captain, retreat you off with your Lady. Tarr, Come hither, and fix thy foot to mine: By this Hilt, if they come on, we'll mawle 'em.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Is there any Plunder to be got, Boy? This scouring for nothing, is such cold Work‚Äî

div.stage: Enter La Mure and Bourcher, with their Swords drawn‚Äîand three more.

sp.speaker: La Mur.
sp.p: O Diable! Rascal! Robera Teefe! V'ere are yee? Vat hoa! Iacka, Petra, Tobee! Vere are ye all, Sons of Whore? I am robbe: Oh Jernee! Mondieu. Here de are! fall on.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p:
Harkee, Diable! Rascale! Teefe! or what do you call your
self? Get you gon, or I shall so pink your Guts, d'ee hear?

sp.speaker: La Mur.
sp.p: Morbleu, Villain! pinka my Guts. Courage.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Nay, if you will be paunch'd, have at your French paunch.

sp.speaker: Bourch.
sp.p: What, hoa, Watch! Watch! Thieves, Thieves, murder.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Sirrah, I'le spoil your Cackling presently.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Stand, who goes there?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Constable, you are come opportunely: Here are a Company of disguis'd Turks, wou'd have Committed a rape upon a Lady just now; if it had not bin for this Gentleman, and my self.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: How, Turks in my Territories!

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Notorious ones. They are all hous'd within there.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Do I represent the Kings Person, and suffer Mahomet under my Nose, hah?

sp.speaker: La Mur.
sp.p: Monsieur Constable, Monsieur Constable!

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Seize, Seize him, Mr. Constable. He is a Mufti; and came over from St. Omers, with Doctor what d'ee call him?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: A Mufti! down with him, down with him, I say.

sp.speaker: La Mur.
sp.p: Why, Monsieur Constable, vat you do? Is de Teevil in you?

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: Search the House, search the House‚Äî

sp.speaker: Du Pier.
sp.p:
Come
‚Ä¢ arr, let's put off now: And go aboard immediately: I think the Coast is clear‚Äî

div.head: ACT II. Scene I.
div.stage: A Tempestuous Sea. Thunder and Lightning

sp.speaker: Ro'ds.
sp.p: LAy her aloof: the Sea grows Boistrous: How it spits against the Clouds! how it Capers! And how the Thunder-thumping Element frights it back‚ÄîThere are Devils dancing Air, I think; I saw a Dolphin just now hang in the Horns of the Moon‚Äîshot from a Wave! Hey, how she kicks! how she yerks! Down with the Main Mast there, lay her at Hull. Furle up her Linnens, and let her ride it out.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p: She'll never brook it, Master: She's so deep Laden, that she'll bulge.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: We have discover'd the Land, Sir; pray let's make in, she's so drunk, she may chance to cast up her Lading.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: Stand in, Stand in. We are all lost else.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Steer her a Starboard there. What, hoa! call up the Boatswain. Holloa‚Äîbelow there!

div.stage: Enter Boatswain, Marine, Du Pier, Franvil, Frugal, Hazard, Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p: What says my Master? what shall we do? We must cast up all her Lading: She will not swim an hour else.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What comfort, Master? I never saw, since I've known the Sea, so rude a Tempest! In what condition are we?

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Dangerous enough, Sir. We have sprung five Leaks; and no little ones; Besides, her Ribs are open: and Rudder almost spent: But come, have good Courage. Death comes out once, and let him come in all his fury.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p: The Storm is so lowd, we cannot hear one another.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: What's the Coast.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p: We know not yet. Let's bear in with all the Sail we can.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Master, see what a Thunder-clap is coming: Oh Lord! how dreadful it looks.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Ye fearful Rogue. Sirrah, thou hast bin praying, I see it in thy Face; thou hast bin mumbling, when we are splitting. You Slave, is this a time to discourage your Friends with your Cold Ejaculations: Sirrah‚Äîlet me but see thee look Religiously agen, and I'le flea thee, as I would an Eele.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Is't not possible to make in to the Land? 'Tis here before us.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Here, hard by, Sir.

sp.speaker: Boldsp.
sp.p: Death is nearer, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Why, there's another Rogue now with his Bagpipes: Prithee, Dear Captain, give me leave to throw that Maudlin Fellow over-board.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Come let's go in, and read.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Ay, come‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Let's hoist the Boat out, and go all at one Cast; the more the merrier.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Hold, you are too hasty, Captain; d'ee long to be in the Fish-market, before your time? hold her up there‚ñ™

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Oh miserable Fortune!

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: So! now we are like to have rare Musick?

sp.speaker: Chapl.
sp.p: Mercy, mercy, what will become of us? Pray, Gentlemen‚Äîpray.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Lookee! prithee, my Dear; no more words now, by this Light‚Äîthou art the most unseasonable Rogue in a Storm. Nay, prithee be gone.

sp.speaker: Chapl.
sp.p: Pray, Gentlemen; pray, pray‚Äî

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Nothing but horrour sounding in my Ears: No promise of rest to my poor frighted Soul! gentle Master, is there no hopes?

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: None, that I know! Dev'l, Clap this Woman under hatches.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Prithee speak mildly to her. Have patience, Sweet.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Keep her thus, keep her thus.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Oh, that Wave will devour me! Oh‚Äî

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Carry her down, Captain‚Äîor by these hands I'le give no more Direction. We have ne're better Luck, when we have such Stowage as these Trinckets with us. These sweet Sin-breeders; how can Heaven smile on us‚Äîwhen such a Burthen of Iniquity‚Äîlyes tumbling like a potion in the Ships belly.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: What shall I do, my Heart and Senses fail me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come in with me. And try if thou canst sleep:
Thy pretty Heart wild-fears so long have rock'd;
Calm rest will steal upon it.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Oh Marine,

div.l: Remember, 'tis for you I meet these Dangers.
For you, expose my self to Seas and Horrors, and fears innumerable.

sp.speaker: Marine.
sp.p: I know thou do'st.
And think too, I have treasur'd the Remembrance within me here, fast lock'd up in my heart; and yet I doubt not but a Day will come‚ÄîTo Crown our flourishing Loves, and make us happy.

div.stage: Enter Boldsprite, Du Pier, Franvil, Frug. Hazard, Surgeon, and Boatswain.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Throw out the Lading, it must all over-board.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p: It clears to Sea ward, Master: Heave out there: Let's lighten her! all the Meat and the Cakes. We are all gone else. That we may find her Leaks, and hold her up.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p:
Must my goods over too? Kind, honest Master: Why, here lies all my Money‚Äîthe Money I have rak'd by
Usury, to buy new Lands and Mannors in new Countreys.‚ÄîI have been these 20 years a raising.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Over with it.
The Devils are got together by the Ears, who shall have it.‚ÄîAnd here they quarrel in the Clouds.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Oh, I am undone!

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Hang ye, Mungrels, would you be only happy?

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Save but one Chest of Plate!

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Away with it lustily, Sailers; it was some Pawn that he has got unjustly, down with it low enough; and let Crabs breed in't.

sp.speaker: Boldsp.
sp.p: Over with the Truncks too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Take mine, and spare not.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Nay, nay; all that has weight must go.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will you throw away my Lordship, that I sold, to buy me a fine Wardrobe‚ÄîFor pity's sake, be favourable to my fine Wardrobe.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Over with it‚ÄîI love to see a Lordship sink. My Friend, you left no Wood upon't, to buoy it up, you might have sav'd it else.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: For my part, I have nothing of weight, but my Prayer-Book: And that, I am resolv'd, shall not burden the Ship. There 'tis.‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Why, well said!

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Come, come, Lieutenant, you may lose too.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Thou ly'st: I have nothing to lose, but my Maidenhead, my Skin, my Cloaths, my Sword here, and my Self, two Crowns in my Pocket, two pair of Cards, and three false Dice‚ÄîI can swim like a Fish, Rascal, nothing to hinder me.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p: In with her of all hands.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Come Captain, come Gentlemen: Ye must all help, my Life now for the Land. 'Tis high, and very Rocky.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: However, let's attempt it.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Then Cheer lustily, my Hearts, and away with her.

div.head: SCENE, a Barren Island.
div.stage: Enter Sebastian, and Nicusa, savagely drest.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: IT must be a Ship‚ÄîI see it now; a tall Ship, she has wrought lustily for her Deliverance! Heav'ns Mercy! what a dismal Day has here been?

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.p:
To still and quiet Minds that know no Miseries, it may seem
wretched; but with us 'tis ordinary. Heav'n has no Storm in store, nor Earth no Terror, that can seem new to us.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: 'Tis true, my Son;
If Fortune were determin'd to be wanton,
And wou'd wipe out the story of Mens Miseries,
Yet we two, living still, should cross her purpose:
Canst thou see 'em? Do they live still?

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.p: Yes: and make to Shore!

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Most miserable Men, I pity 'em.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.p: What Shouts of Joy they make?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Alas! poor Wretches!
Had they but once Experience of this Island,
They'd turn their Shouts to Howlings.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: Nay, to Curses!
That ever they set Foot on this fad place.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Sad indeed: where nothing is but Rocks and Barrenness;
Hunger and Cold‚ÄîHere's no Vineyards
To cheer the Heart of Man: Nor Chrystal Rivers,
After his Labour, to refresh his Body;
If he be Feeble, nothing to restore him,
But Heav'nly Hopes: Nature, that made those Remedies,
Dares not come here, nor look on our Distresses,
For fear she turn Wild, like the place, and Barren.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: Then, Sir, the memory of what we were,
When we were seated in our blessed Homes,
Gives us a double Misery.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Oh Curse on those French Pirates that displanted us,
And drove me from my Wife and pretty Children,
To live a wretched Life, upon this fatal Island.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.p: They are living yet, I hope, Sir; such Goodness Cannot perish.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: They may live‚Äîbut never to me, my Son,
Never to me again‚ÄîLook on't‚ÄîWhat bear
Their Flagg-staves?

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: The Arms of England.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: They get to Shore apace. What's that which Swims?

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: A strong young Man! with a hansom
Woman hanging about his Neck.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: A Noble Fellow, I warrant him!
May this brave Charity, who e're thou art,
Be spoken in a place that may renown thee,
And not dye here.

sp.speaker: Nicu.
sp.l: Their Boat it seems turn'd over,
And forc'd them to their Shifts, yet all are landed‚Äî
They are certainly Pyrates.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Let 'em be what they will, they will not Rob us;
For none will take our Misery for Riches;
Come, Son, let us descend, and try their Pities;
If we get off, we have a little hopes;
If not, we shall but load this wretched Island
With the same Shaddows still that must grow shorter.

div.stage: Enter Marine, Aminta, Du Pier, Boldsprite, Franvil, Frugal, Hazard, Boatswain, Surgeon, and Sailers.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Wet come a Shore, my Hearts; we are safe arriv'd tho'.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thanks to Heavens Goodness! and no Man lost neither, but the poor Chaplain.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Ay‚Äîthe poor Soul-Broker's gone, he was wash'd, with a Wave, off the Quarter-Deck‚ÄîI saw his Cassock and he fluttering between Wind and Water, a great while‚ÄîWell, Peace be with him, he was too good for us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The Weather's turn'd more Courteous: and the Ship rides fair too, and her Leaks in good plight:
How does my Dear? Alas, poor Heart!
How weak she is, and wet!

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: I am glad I escap'd with Life:
For which, Dear Captain, I am oblig'd to you:
Oh let the Heav'ns but bless me with a means
How to reward such Love, and I am happy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This Rosy kiss rewards me ten times o're,
And this ten thousand.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: I cannot speak for Joy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Dearest Life‚ÄîWell, what cheer, my Lads?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Faith! no great Cheer, Captain! a piece of Sous'd Bisket, and half a hard Egg: For the Sea has taken order, being young and strong, we shall not surfeit: For my own part, the Water has made a mear Toste of me; I am sopt rarely: However, I'le Dance‚ñ™ till I am dry: Come, Surgeon, out with your Glister-pipe, Sirrah, and strike a Galliard.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, what a brave day is here? And what fair Weather, after so foul a Storm?

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Ay, if the Master had not been bewitch'd, he might have foreseen this Weather, and have sav'd our Goods! Oh my dear Plate and Jewels! Oh my dear Money! Vengeance on the Master.

sp.speaker: Franv.
sp.p: Ay, and twenty small Curses beside; I have lost my fine Wardrobe; oh insupportable! the Ladies will hate me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh never think on 'em: VVe have our Lives and Healths!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: For my part I've lost nothing, but my Pray'r Book: I sav'd my other Cargo, my bale of Dice: therefore I am happy.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Not think of 'em, Sir! I must and will think of 'em: And that 'twas most maliciously done, to undo me

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And me too: I lost all: I had fifteen fair Suits: the worst of 'em Embroider'd; and now I ha'n't so much as a Shirt left.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, hast not, Faith?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, by this Light; nor ragg of Cloaths neither, but these poor things.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Give me thy hand: I am glad on't with all my Heart. Is thy Skin whole?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Sir, you may spare your Raillery.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Faith, I shannot! Harkee, wilt thou see a Dog- fish now rise in one of thy brave Doublets? And tumble like a Tub, to make thee merry? Or an Old Haddock rise with thy Beaver Hat on? A Mermaid in a Wastcoat of your Worships; or a Dolphin with your Point Crevat?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You are merry, Sir; but if I take it thus‚Äîif I be foisted and jeer'd out of my VVardrobe‚Äî

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Nor I, neither.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Nor will I leave my Friends.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Neither Master, nor Mate, nor none of you shall abuse me: I say our Goods might ha' been sav'd; and I'le have satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, be not angry, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Sir, we have reason: And some Friends I can make.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Why, you Scoundrels! was not what I did for the general Safety? if you aim at me, I am not so tame‚Äî

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: No, nor we neither.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Pray take my Counsel, Gallants: Fight not till the Surgeon be well, d'ee hear? He's damnable Sea-sick yonder: and may spoil all: Besides he has lost his Fiddle-stick‚ÄîAnd the best Box of Boars-grease. Nay‚Äîdo not draw your Swords; for if you do.‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Who would you fight with, Gentlemen? Who has done you wrong? For shame be better temper'd; no sooner come to give thanks for our safeties, but we must raise new Civil Broils among us‚ÄîPut up, put up, for shame.‚Äî

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We have been wrong'd, Sir, and damnably too.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Nay, lookee; if you will needs fight, and think to raise new Riches by your Valours, come‚Äîhave at you: I have little else to do now: I have said my Prayers‚ÄîYou say you have lost, and make your Loss your Quarrel, and grumble at my Captain here, and the Master: two worthy Persons, indeed, too worthy for such Rescals‚ÄîCome you Wardrobe Gallant, come on: and you, Money Merchant, that build on Golden Monuments in Potosi. Come, draw all your Swords, ye say ye are miserable?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Put up, Gentlemen, or, by this light, he'll swinge you damnably‚ÄîI see't in's Face.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Captain stand by a little: And see how I'le correct 'em. I'le make 'em ten times poorer‚ÄîI will not leave 'em‚Äîfor look you, fighting is as nourshing to me, as eating: I was born quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come, they'l Consider.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: I will not leave 'em skin to cover 'em: there's no joint shall stand in's proper place. D'ee grumble when you are well, you Rogues?

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: A Devilish Fellow this Lieutenant. Gad he has quash'd me already.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: 'Scape drowning, and d'ee prate?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Pray, Gentlemen, for my sake be quiet; let it become me to make all Friends.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We have so much breeding, not to deny a Lady any thing: Come let's put up.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Ay, ay: We were to blame, to draw before the Lady, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: This Passion, and too much Courage, is a damnable fault.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: 'Tis well, 'tis very well: There's half a Bisket, break it amongst you all, and thank my Bounty; that is Cloaths and Plate too now. Come no more quarrels.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ha! in the name of wonder, what have we here? Are they humane Creatures?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: I have heard of Sea-Calves.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: They are no shadows sure, they have legs and arms.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Ay, they hang but scurvily on though.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: What Beards they have?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: They have sown Horse Tails to their Faces, to keep‚Äî'em warm.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: How their Eyes are sunk, as if they had bin frighted; sure they are wretched Men?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: There are Wardrobes for you: Look you, my Friend, what do you think of these now for a Couple of Courtiers?

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: They kneel, sure they would beg something.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What are you? Speak, are you Substances, or wandring shadows, that find no peace on Earth, till you reveal some secret?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: We are Men as you are, onely our Miseries make us seem Monsters; if ever pity dwelt in noble Hearts‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Stand up, and speak boldly.

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.p:
If you are Christians, and by that blessed Name bound to
‚Ä¢ elieve us. Convey us from this Island.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Speak‚Äîwhat are you?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Of honourable Birth; to tell you more,
VVere but to number up our own Calamities,
And make our Eyes wilde with perpetual weepings;
This many years, in this most wretched Island
VVe two have liv'd, the Scorn and Game of Fortune,
Bless your selves from it! noble Gentlemen!
The greatest plagues that Humane Nature suffers,
Are seated here: VVildness and VVants innumerable.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How came you hither?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: In a small Vessel: Driven hither by French Pyrates, to save my VVealth from those insulting Robbers.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: French Pyrates! Oh my heart!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Is all the Island uninhabited?

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.p: Most desolate, neither Man nor Beast to comfort or sustain us.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: No summer here to promise any thing,
Nor Autumn to make full the Reapers hand;
The Earth, obdurate to the Tears of Heav'n,
Let's nothing shoot or grow, but poisonous VVeeds:
No Rivers, nor no pleasant Groves: No Beasts.
All that were made for Man's use, flye this place.
Serpents, and ugly things, the shames of Nature.
Roots of malignant tastes, foul standing VVaters,
Sometimes we finde a fulsome Sea Root,
And that's a Delicate; a Rat sometimes,
And that we hunt, like Princes in their pleasure;
And if we take a Toad, we make a Banquet.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Oh Lord! we shall be starv'd too! Mercy on us, eat a Toad! did he say?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: VVould I were at home agen with my dear Matrimony, I begin to be weary of rambling.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, let's aboard, I would discourse with this Fellow; for my mind gives me, he can tell me something of my Father?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: D'ee know no farther?

sp.speaker: Nicusa.
sp.l: VVe have sometimes seen the shadow of a place
Inhabited: And heard the noise of Hunters.
And have attempted to find it as far as a River,
Deep, slow, and dangerous, fenc'd with high Rocks,
VVould give us leave; but not able to atchieve that hazard,
Return'd to our old miseries: And, Gentlemen,
If this sad story may deserve your pities‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You shall aboard with us; we will relieve you.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: VVe will not be unthankful for this Benefit;
No, Gentlemen, we'll pay for our deliverance‚ñ™
Look you, that plough the Sea, for wealth and pleasure,
That out-run Day and Night with your Ambitions:
Look on those heaps, remove 'em, view 'em fully.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: By Heaven, 'tis Gold and Jewels!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: VVhat's that? Gold and Jewels!

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Be not too hasty, here lies another heap.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: And here another; all Gold! by this Light.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Stand farther off, you must not be your own Carvers.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: VVe have shares, and large ones‚ÄîI'le have my Plate and Money made good.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And I my VVard-robe.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Ay, and we'll Carve our selves too. VVhat hoa! Fellow-Sailers, stand to your freedoms: Gold, gold.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Take heed, Gentlemen;
This Gold was the overthrow of my happiness.
For landing here with a party of Negro-Slaves,
That I commanded to assist me against the Pyrates:
This cursed Gold enticing 'em, they set upon me, and my Son here; wounded us almost to Death.
And then their Civil Swords, who should be owners:
First in their rage, consum'd the Vessel that brought us,
And next themselves by heaps. Oh be you wise and careful.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Tell not me of Care, Sir‚Äîholloa! All that will share with us‚Äîassist us. I'le have all this.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And I this.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: You shall be hang'd first: Captain, let's set in.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This Damn'd Gold will undo us all.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: My Losses must be made good.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And so must mine; or else this Sword shall right me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay if you will be Dogs‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Let me come, Captain.
This Golden Age must have an Iron ending:
Have at the Bunch.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Stay, dear Marine! Lieutenant, oh Heavens! what will become of us?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Now Fortune favour us. Come Son, if we stay here, we dye: Here rides their Ship. Whilst they are gone to the spoil‚Äîlet us make quick use, and get off.

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.p: Away‚ÄîDear Father.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: This Gold was our overthrow.

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.p: It may be now our happiness.

div.stage: Re-enter Marine, Du Pier, and the rest.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: You shall have Gold: Yes! I'le cram it into you‚Äîyou shall be your own Carvers, yes; I'le carve you, base greedy Rogues. Captain, let's make an end of 'em.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No‚Äîhang 'em, though they are Villains, yet they are our Countrey-men: prithee Master get the Boat ready, and let's aboard.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh, I am hurt to Death.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: And I‚Äîmy Leg is almost cut off‚ÄîOh.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Oh Captain, we are undone, we are undone; all miserable! ruin'd‚Äîlost‚Äîthe ship‚Äîthe Ship.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What of her?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Oh she's under sail, and floating: See where she flies‚Äîsee to your shames, you Wretches, those poor starv'd things that shew'd us Gold, have chous'd us.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: We are snapt finely.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p: They have cut her Cables, and got her out: The Tide too has befriended them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh damn'd misfortune! why, where were all the Saylers that kept her?

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Here in the mutiny, to take up Money, with a Pox to 'em: And left no Creature; left the Boat a shore too. Oh this Gold! This damn'd bewitching Gold.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Oh we shall be starv'd, we shall be starv'd.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Come back, good Men; come back, good old Men‚Äî

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Come back, good honest Men.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Come back, good Men, come back: Yes, 'tis very likely they will! D'ee look like Dogs now? Are your mighty Courages abated?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: This is the worst of miseries: Oh what shall we do?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Retire, Sir, and comfort her, and let us make the best use of our Misfortune: I'le but vex these Rascals a little, and come to you straight‚Äî

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Oh I am hurt and hungry, hurt and hungry, very hungry.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Here's a pestle of a Portigue, Sir. 'Tis excellent meat, with soure Sawce: And here's two Chains, you may suppose 'em Sawsages: Then there wants Mustard; but the Surgeon there will supply that presently with Salves.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: My Salves, and all my Instruments are lost, and I am hurt and starv'd.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p:
Starv'd! what in a Land that flows with Milk and Honey!
a second Canaan! Come, Faith, let's go all to supper.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ay, where's the meat?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Where's the meat? VVhy, what a Veal voice is there?

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Veal‚Äîgad would we had it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ay, or Mutton either: tho' 'twere of a rotten Sheep that dy'd in a Ditch.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Now would I cut your throats ye Dogs; but that I won't do you such a Courtesie to keep you from the Benefit of starving; which will be, and suddenly; unless you can eat Mud, and fancy 'tis Custard; to which excellent repast, I leave ye: Your first Couse is serv'd up. Expect the second hereafter‚Äî

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Ah, Pox o' these Jewels.

sp.speaker: Fran. Haz.
sp.p: Oh this Cursed Gold.‚Äî

div.head: ACT III. Scene I.
A flat Rock.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: NO Comfort yet, nor hopes of a relief,
No welcome Plant, or wholsome Fruit to help us,
Against oppressing Famine: Oh Heaven!
To what Fate do our Cruel Stars reserve us!
How does my Dear, art thou not faint and weak?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Not much; your Company is still a Cordial to me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You good Angels, that are ingag'd, when our Ability
Fails, to reward Virtue, look on this Lady;
For me, tho' Famine gripes my Croaking Entrai's,
Yet when I kiss these lips, methinks
I am at a Banquet; a refreshing Banquet.
Speak, my Dearest life, art thou not hungry?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Indeed, I could eat to keep you company.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Blush, unkind Nature! Canst thou supply a Drunkard?
And with a prodigal hand give choice of VVines,
Till he disgorge thy Blessings? Or a Glutton,
That robs the Element, to sooth his Pallat;
And onely Eats to beget Appetite,
Not to be satisfy'd? And suffer here
A Virgin, which the Saints wou'd make their Guest,
To pine for hunger.
Hah, if my Sense
Deceive me not, these sounds take Being
From the breath of Men: Confirm me, dear Aminta‚ñ™
This way the gentle Wind convey's it to us;
Hear you nothing?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Yes, plainly; it seems the Hunters Musick.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Still 'tis louder: And I remember the two Portugals
Inform'd us, they had often heard such sounds;
But ne're could touch the Shore from whence they came.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Nor is it to be hop'd we shall: This envious
Torrent's cruelly interpos'd to hinder us, and we
Have no Vessel that may transport us:
Nor has Nature given us Wings to flye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Better try all hazards,
Than perish here remediless.
To serve my sweet Aminta,
These Arms shall be my Oars, with which I'le swim,
And my Zeal, to save thy precious Innocence,
Like wings shall bear me up spite of these horrid waves.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Will you then leave me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But for a moment, Sweet: And believe,
Tho' pleasure met me in most ravishing Form;
And happiness courted me to entertain her,
I would not eat, nor sleep, till I return'd;
And Crown'd thee with my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Oh but your Absence, and my Fears, what mischief
May happen to you in that Fatal place,
Will certainly distract me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Suppose it but a Dream, and try to sleep.
Think you have sent me for discovery
Of some most fortunate Continent, yet unknown;
Which you are to be Queen of.
And all ye Powers, that Value Lovers prayers,
Or Cherish true affection, guard my Love
In your protection, let her cease to mourn,
Nor sigh, or shed a Tear till my return.

div.stage: Scene draws off, and discovers a Grotto, and Rosy Bower, plac'd in the midst of a pleasant Country. And Roselia seated high, with Clarinda, Hippolita, Julietta, Menalippe, Aglaura, Ariadne, Clita, and other Ladies, all drest in Amazonian Habits, plac'd about her.

lg.l: LIberty's the Soul of Living,
Every hour new Ioys receiving;
No sharp Pangs our hearts are grieving,
Liberty's the Soul of Living.
Here are no false Men pursuing
Youth or Beauty to its Ruine
Murmuring sighs, like Turtles Cooing;
Nor the bitter Sweets of Wooing.
Liberty's the Soul of Living,
Liberty's the Soul of Living.
In soft dreams our Souls are wasted,
All our solid Ioys are blasted.
Sweet Diana, e're I'm past it,
Change thy Law, and let me taste it.
But how vain are Hopes or Sorrows,
Pensive Nights, or sighing Morrows
Love's a Prey, not destin'd for us.
All our Quivers want their Arrows.
There's no Liberty like Loving,
There's no Liberty like Loving.

lg.head: Chorus of Both.
lg.l: Then since, we are doom'd to be Chaste;
And loving is counted a Crime,
We'll to our new Pleasures make haste.
Sing, Revel, and laugh out our Time,
And do what we can,
Not to think of a Man,
But make the best use of our Prime.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: They that say Women are not fit to Govern,
Betray their weakness, and their want of Knowledge:
For what Perfection is there in the Male,
That is not in the Female: Grant, their Composure stronger,
Their Bodies Courser, and more fit for Wars,
Which some of us, do haply contradict:
I cannot yet Conceive, why this shou'd bind us
To be their Slaves; our Souls are Male as theirs;
And that we have hitherto forborn t'assume,
And mannage Thrones: I say, altho' we have not
Challeng'd a Soveraignty in Arts and Arms;
And writ our selves Imperial, hath bin
Mens Tyranny, and our Modesty‚Äînot defects,
Or want of Judgment: Blest be then the hour
That threw me on this Shore, inhabited by Warlike Women,
That keep men in Subjection: And by them, chosen to rule:
Where, since I lost Sebastian, and Nicusa;
My Husband, and dear Son, by those French Pyrates;
All others of their Sex have met my hate.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: And shall they still do so?

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: For ever, Girl!
Thou darling of my life: my Dear Clarinda,
I say for ever.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And must I always dream, and dream then, and to no purpose‚Äîby this light I will have a Husband, or she shall never live a good day.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: Nay, the Protectress is too severe, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Iuliet.
sp.p: Because she's Old, she thinks every one has as little Occasion for a Husband, as her self: But she's mistaken in me, I can assure Her.

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: Ay, and in me too.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: And therefore more to confirm my Resolution,
That we may still keep out insulting Man,
I here appoint, when-e're I chance to dye,
That the succession fall on my Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Madam, with humblest Duty,
I pay my thanks: but fear the Common-wealth
Will murmur at this positive Election;
She being always chosen to Govern here,
That's voted by the People, as you were‚Äî

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Which Custome shall continue. We'll have no Arbitrary proceedings.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: No: nor will we have our Privileges impos'd upon, unless she will give us Men.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: What's that you murmur about men?

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: Men! Out upon 'em, I'le assure your Highness, our thoughts are‚Äî

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Of nothing else, if the truth were known.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Once more I vote Clarinda my Successor:
And will in this Position be obey'd,
Or like a storm my Rage lets loose upon ye:

div.p: I give you leave to consider‚ÄîMenalippe, Clita, follow me. You are too young to ingage in private Factions: And therefore meet my pitty‚Äîbut for the rest‚Äî
Let them take heed, how they my Will debate, Or act a Crime they may repent too late.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: She behaves her self, as if she were Immortal,
Or as the Sun, or she had equal Influence,
And did oblige the World with mutual Blessings.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: If such Pride as this hold long, we are like to have a hopeful Government.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: Ay, and without Men too, to keep us Company, And be Civil to us, I assure ye: my Dears, now we are alone, and have liberty to speak our thoughts, In my Opinion, this usage of our Protectress is not to be endur'd.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Endur'd! by my Virginity, 'tis downright Tyranny: For I confess, for my own part, I have no liking to this single solitary Life; nor do I love hunting other Creatures so well, but I had as lieve be hunted my self.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Nor I, by Venus.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: By Venus! by Diana, I hope you meant to swear, Hippolita? she, you know, had the most Virtues.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: It may be so: But I'm sure t'other had the most Wit.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: Very fine: I wish you could influence the Protectress with this Doctrine.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Pox on her, nothing can influence an old Woman, but a Iulip.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: Oh, Eringo's, or an Ownce or two of Green Ginger, would work admirable Effects.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I know not what Consolation she may have, but if I have any Comfort in this life, but when I sleep, I am a Whore.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: A Whore! Oh Venus! what a sweet charming luscious honey word, has this raw Creature thrown away‚ÄîA Whore! what the Devil, would you be an Angel?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Would I were a VVhore upon a good account.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Or I either: Oh little England's a sweet place for this purpose, the VVhores have as much respect there as the Women of Quality.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: And more than their Wives, I hear, a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
But you were talking of Dreams, Sweet-heart: And last night I had the sweetest sure, that ever woman had; for methought as I
was lying in my Cabine, a fine young brisk, well shap'd man, stole softly to me all unbutton'd, and taking me in his Arms, kiss'd me, on my Conscience, above twenty times.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: Deuce take you: You have made my mouth run with water.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Lord! what a man is this, thought I, to do this to a Maid: And so stretching out my Arms, thinking to Catch him fast‚Äî

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You wak'd, and found nothing‚Äî

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Even so: Therefore the Devil take all false Figures, I say.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And so say I too: For my part I have wish'd the Statues in the Garden had bin real, a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Come, Ladies, are you not for hunting?
VVe dull our selves for want of Exercise.
There's not a guilded Hour adorns the day;
But smiling, greets us with some new adventure;
Away for shame, and clog not your clear bloods
VVith that perpetual Bane of Beauty, Idleness.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Madam, we wait on you: Who rouz'd the Stag?

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: Clarinda, and in the instant, Lodg'd a Steel-Headed Arrow in his Hanch, VVith which he's fled.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Ha, what's this comes here?

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: By all that's good, a man: shall I shoot him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No, no: 'Tis a handsome Beast, sure.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: VVould we had more o' the Breed, really 'tis a very Comely Creature.

div.p: Let's hear if it can speak?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: VVhat Heavenly place is this?
VVhere Beings more than humane keep their Residence?
Sure I have past the Baleful stygian Gulf?
And now touch on the blessed Shore: 'Tis so,
This is Elizium: And these the happy Spirits;
That here enjoy all pleasures.

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: He comes towards us! O Lord! won't it eat me?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Stand, or I'le shoot.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Hold‚Äîhe makes no resistance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Be not offended Goddesses, that I fall
Thus prostrate at your feet? Or, if not such,
But Nymphs of Diana's Train, that range these Groves;
Which you forbid to men: Vouchsafe to know,
That tho' I am a man, I am not sold
So far to Impudence, as to presume
To press upon your privacies for my self,
No, that I am an humble Suiter to you,
Is for a Virgin‚ÄîComes as near your selves
In all perfection, as what's mortal may
Resemble things Divine: O pity her,
And let your Charity free her from you Desart;
If Heavenly Charity can reach to Hell.
For sure that place comes near it: And where e're
This wretched frame of mine shall find a Being,
Eternally I shall pour Blessings on you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: By my Maden-head I cannot hurt him now:
Well, some of these mankind have strange influences.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.l: Really, 'tis the finest thing that ever I saw in my life:
Wou'd he wou'd come and kiss me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Cruel Hippolita, how could'st thou find in thy Heart to kill him?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Madam, if I had done it, I had but obey'd your Mother's Commands.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: If she Commands unjust and Cruel things,
We are not to obey her.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Oh, sits the Wind there?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Pray see what an excellent shape it has?
Why should it be infectious?

sp.speaker: Aglau.
sp.p: I have heard my Mother say, I had a Father: And was not he a Man?

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.l: Questionless, Madam.

sp.speaker: Aglau.
sp.l: Your Fathers too, were men?

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.l: Without doubt.

sp.speaker: Aglau.
sp.l: And without such, it is impossible
We cou'd have bin.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: A sin against Nature, to deny it.

sp.speaker: Aglau.
sp.p: Nor can we ever hope to be made Mothers without 'em.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: Never, never; 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Ay, by my faith is it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why, how then could you have design of killing the likeness of the thing by which you are.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Only in obedience to your Mother.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Age is not sensible of it's own Barbarity. I swear I am resolv'd to defend and keep him.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: For your own Use.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: Nay, if you are resolv'd on't, I'le assist you.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: And all of us.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Well, I see by instinct, though a Maid have never seen a Man; there are some certain motions that inform her‚Äîbut here's the Protectress; now I expect a Storm.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Child of my flesh,
But stranger to my fair unspotted mind;
Unhand this Monster.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Monster, Mother!

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Yes, Monster, I say Monster.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Would I had him alone in my Cave for all that;
I should not be affraid he would swallow me.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Whose every word is as a Syrens note,
To drown the careless hearer: Have I not taught the
The falsehood, and the perjuries of men?
On whom, but for a woman to shew pity,
Is to be cruel to her self: The Soveraignty,
Proud and Imperious men usurp upon us,
We confer on our selves. And love those Fetters
we fasten to our freedoms. Have we, Clarinda,
E're since Sebastian's loss, thy noble Father,
Planted our selves here in Common-VVealth,
VVith execrable Oaths, never to look
On man, but as a Monster; and wilt thou
Be the first President, to infringe those Vows
VVe made to Heaven?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Vows made in heat, and wild temerity, VVith Heaven, still pass for nothing. Alas! Madam, should women always use this rigid abstinence, in a few years the whole world would be peopled only with Beasts. Besides, pray look on him: Is there not something nobler in his Face, Than graces others?

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: Spoke to the purpose, Madam: Let's speak well of the man now we have him‚ÄîCome, come, there's but few of the sort.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: VVe must, and will have the man: therefore speak boldly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Clita
sp.l: Ay‚Äîor we'll shake off all Obedience.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Madam, you'l lose your Subjects hearts for ever,
If you deny this Justice.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Are you all mad?
That no perswasion can have power upon you;
Suppose you had my Suffrage to your Suit,
Can this weak Ship-wrack'd wretch supply you all!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Not together, indeed.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.l: No‚Äîbut by Times, and Turns, he may, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Gracious Lady,
I have Fellows in my misery: Not far hence,
Divided only by that hellish River,
There live a Company of wretched men;
Such as your Charity may make your Slaves;
Imagine all the miseries Mankind
May suffer under: And they groan beneath 'em.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But are they all like you?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Speak they your Language, are they kind men?

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.l: Are they young, healthy men? Come, there's the point.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They were when I left 'em,
And in their May of Youth, and flowing blood,
And such as might deserve you; now cold and hunger
Hath lessen'd their perfection, but restor'd
To what they were, I doubt not they'l appear
VVorthy your favours.

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.l: This is a Blessing we could not hope for.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Dear Mother‚Äîbe not obdurate.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: O thou fond foolish Girl! when thou shalt find
Their Levity, and their Neglect of Love,
Thou't mourn thy easiness, and Curse their Sex.
But come, for once your Suits are granted:
And first, all you that are for the Men, hold up your hands;
Very well.
Now you, whose colder Blood, and chaster Tempers
Bid a defiance to loves bewitching Charms,
And flight that Childish God to follow me,
Hold up your hands‚Äîis't possible, not one!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I find the Protectress will have few followers, at this rate?

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.l: We shall have men to follow now.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: Hear then my Resolution; and endeavour not to add to what I grant, for 'twill be fruitless: you shall appear as good Angels to these wretched men.
sp.l: In a small Boat they shall pass over to us,
And crave comfort: If you like their Persons,
And they approve of yours; for we'll force nothing;
Each one shall choose a Husband, and enjoy
His company a Month; but that expir'd,
You shall no more come near 'em: If you prove fruitful,
The Males you shall return to them, the Females
sp.p: We will reserve our selves: This is the utmost you shall obtain, Therefore as you think fit, dismiss this Stranger. And all prepare to morrow for the meeting.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Come, Sir, pray walk with us,
sp.p: We'll shew you the pleasant Groves and Springs, and Grotto's, and you shall eat and drink with us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Excellent Lady!
Tho' 'twill appear a Wonder, one near starv'd
Shou'd refuse Rest and Meat‚ÄîI must not take
Your Noble Offer‚ÄîI left in yonder Desart,
A Virgin almost pin'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: She's not your Wife, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No Madam‚Äîshe's my Sister. 'Tis now dangerous
To speak truth‚Äî
To her I deeply vou'd not to taste Food or Rest,
Till I return'd: Now, if you please
To afford me but an easie passage thither,
And some Convenient Sustenance for her;
I shall for ever bless you, and thankfully
She shall acknowledge to you she owes her life.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You plead so well, I can deny you nothing.
Come in; and I my self will see you furnish'd,
And with the next Sun visit and relieve you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let this declare my thanks.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: This act would prove,
In others gratitude: But in me, 'tis Love.

div.head: SCENE, The Barren Island.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: OH what a Tempest have I in my Stomach? My Guts are grumbling a kind of Tune, Like the Base Pipes of an Organ: I am starv'd into a Substance so thin, that my Body is transparent; you may see my heart, and the appurtenances, hang up here in its mortal Closet, as easily as a Candle in a Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: For my part, I've forgot to eat.

div.p: My Bellies grown together, like an empty Satchel. I have bin throwing a main yonder, to pass away the time: But I can get nothing‚Äîmy Guts grumble still.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I am thinking, Gentlemen, what a happiness‚Äî

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: How's that! have you the Courage to think of any happiness! Gad you have a hoard of meat then, Sirrah. You could never have a happy thought, without the encouragement of Beef, or some such Blessing.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p:
Beef, Rogues, Beef; who the Devil talks of Beef there?
I'le draw. I rage, I storm lowder than the Winds or Weather. I am not naturally Valliant, but to provoke my Courage with the sound of Beef, and give me none, makes me a fury‚ÄîI roar like the Sea: Therefore you happy Rascal, make attonement quickly; or in the name of Famin, I will so grind you‚Äîah‚Äî

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Is the Devil in you? Why I am more starv'd than any of ye, have three times louder Bag-pipes in my Guts. And am ten times as thin, I was diving in the Sea to find Oysters last night, and the Saylers took me for Will with the Wisp‚ÄîThe Moon shone quite through me.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Why, Sirrah, what happiness is that you are thinking of then? Answer me that.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Ay, ay, answer that; the Dog has blood in's face; an apparent sign of nourishment, he has Eaten lately‚ÄîI fee't plainly‚Äîthis Rogue has half an Ox by him, I warrant, in some corner now‚Äîhah‚Äîmy Mouth Waters at the Rascal Confoundedly.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: An Ox! Oh Parradise! 'Sbud, wou'd I had but the Hoof of one, on Condition you were all hang'd‚Äîor any part else that had the honour of belonging to blessed Beef.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Pox on thee, do not talk on't then: Do not charm my starving Intellects, with that most delightful sound‚ÄîNow if I were a great man, the word should be nothing but Beef, through my Kingdome; my Armies should exercise nothing else: And my Butcher should mouth it instead of a Drum.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: When I was speaking of happiness: I was thinking what a pleasure my Dogs had, when I kept House at Home‚Äîthey had a Store-House, a Store-House of most blessed Bones, and Crusts; hard and happy Crusts.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Would I had one to gnaw now: or were but amongst 'em; I'd snarl for a short Dinner with 'em.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Now has this tantalizing Rogue set my Mouth a watering, a second time, with talking of his Hounds.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: A Son of a Whore, when he knows too, that a fat Beagle is as good as a fat Buck‚ÄîAnd that the Loyn of a Bull-dog‚Äî

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Ah, is better than a Loyn of Veal a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Here comes the Woman;
It may be she has meat, and may relieve us,
Let's stand aside and mark, and then be ready‚Äîshe'll hide her
Store else, and so Cozen us.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: How weary, and how faint is all my Body,
My Eyes like spent Lamps, going out, grow
Heavy; my sight forsaking me, and all my Spirits,
As if they heard my passing Bell toll for me,
Take in their Powers, and leave me up to Destiny,
Oh for a little meat! a little water.
I had whole Floods of Tears awhile, that nourisht me,
But they are all consum'd for thee, Marine;
For thou art dead. Oh take my life, sweet Heav'n!
Or make me once more happy in his sight.

sp.speaker: Frug.
