sp.l: She's faln asleep, sure?
Why should she have this Blessing, and we wake?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: This thing has bin our ruine: The Captain had not gone to Sea, but for her sake; and all those mischiefs that are fallen upon us, are come by her means.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Why should we consume thus and starve? Have nothing to relieve us: And she live there that bred our Miseries, unrosted or unboil'd, hah!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Right; I have read in Histories of such restoring Meats: Besides, we have Examples, a thousand Examples, Women that have eaten their Children, Men their Slaves, nay, their Brothers: But these are nothing; Husbands devour'd their Wives. (They are their Chattels.) And of a School-master, that, in time of Famin, powdred up all his Scholars‚Äîshe's young and tidy‚Äîon my Conscience she'll eat delicately, just like young Pork; a little leaner: your Opinion, Surgeon?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: I think she may be good meat; but we shall want Salt.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: A pox, she wants no powdring, Man.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But to suck out the humorous parts: by all means let's kill her in a Chafe; she'll eat the sweeter.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Let's kill her any way, and kill her quickly; that we may go to supper.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: But how if the Captain‚Äî

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh‚Äîhe's dead, and the rest famish'd. Come, wake her,

sp.speaker: Surgeon.
sp.p: Cut her throat, and then divide her; Every man his share.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Hush‚Äîshe wakes her self‚Äî

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Who's there! Oh, Gentlemen! give me some Food, or else I perish: I am just now dying.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: You'l save a labour then: You bred our miseries,
And you shall pay for't: We have no meat;
But all are sick and famisht: However, e're
We dye, we'll have one dainty meal.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Shall I be with you, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.l: Yes, marry shall you; in our Bellies, sweet Lady:
You see we love you well.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: What said you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.l: Why, Faith, only we'll eat your Ladiship, that's all.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Come, come: Say your prayers, that I may perform‚Äî
We are wondrous sharp set. Come, Gentlemen‚ñ™
Who are for the „Äà‚óä„Äâ parts?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I, I.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.l: I, I.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Pray be patient: They will not fall to every ones share.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Oh, hear me! hear me, you barbarous Men!

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Not a word‚Äî

div.stage: Enter Marine with a Basket of meat. Du Pier, Boldsprite, Boatswain, Sailers.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: The Lady's Voice! stand off, Slaves! How now,
What d'ee intend, Villains?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Oh, my dear Friend!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My kindest, best Aminta! see, what I have brought thee?

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.l: ‚ÄîThese Rogues would have ravish'd her.
Speak, how was it, Lady?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Forgive 'em, 'Twas their hungers.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Their Hungers! Choak 'em, they would have eaten her!
Oh damn'd Canibals! speak, is it true?

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.l: For my part, I confess an appetite.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: An appetite! I'll fit you for your appetite! since you would be such Devils! why did you not begin with one another handsomely? And spare the Woman to beget more Food on?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: For my sake spare 'em, Lieutenant: And pray come into the Cave, and eat with us.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Stir not within forty foot of this Food, if you do, Dogs‚Äî

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Oh Lieutenant! Lieutenant! Dear noble Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come Master, and honest Sailers: Let's go in: Oh my Dear! I have strange news to tell thee: I have discover'd a new World, a Paradise of Angels, such as thou art; that have supply'd me with these Meats and Drinks. We shall see 'em to morrow, and they'l relieve us further: I'le tell thee more within.
sp.l: And with Devotion thank the Powr's above,
For giving me this means to serve my Love.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Thou best of men! how am I bound to thee.

div.head: ACT IV. Scene I.
A Barren Island.
div.stage: Enter La Mure, Bourchier, Sebastian, and Nicusa.

sp.speaker: La Mur.
sp.p: FInd d'em out quickly, vid out excuse or delays, or begar your Troate sal be Cut.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, we left 'em here: But you see the place is fatal, and who knows but they may be starv'd, and dead, and rotten.

sp.speaker: La Mur.
sp.p: Rotten: De Dev'la rot 'em! dat is no matre, I vil have my revenge on d'em; dead or alive! Morbleu! I vil search every Corner of de World, but I vill have d'em.

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.p: You see these Foot-steps, and the tracks new made, shew that they have bin here‚Äîhah! and see a further discovery‚Äîwhat's that moves there upon the River?

sp.speaker: Bourc.
sp.p: I see it now plainly. 'Tis a Vessel, and throng'd with people‚ÄîThey seem as sailing over to that other Country there.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: 'Tis they, Sir. I know the Captain by his Feather; and if you observe narrowly, look yonder, you may see the Woman too.

sp.speaker: La Mur.
sp.p: Oh Diable! it is she, begar I know her.

sp.speaker: Bour.
sp.p: But how is't possible they should get thither?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: That indeed is most difficult: And much I wonder by what strange adventure they had this help: Yet thus far I can advise you, whil'st we were Crusing up and down, before you took us, we chanc'd to touch upon a place, govern'd by Women, and went by night on shore to get fresh Water: Thither, as I suppose, that Vessel's gone; for it lies Westward.

sp.speaker: La Mur.
sp.p: Shew us de vay, make us come thither, or begar you sal be no living Creature.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Sir, I'le do the best I can, tho' I am but an ill Pilot.

sp.speaker: La Mur.
sp.p: Look to't: For if you fail, expect no mercy.

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.p: Was ever Fate like ours, to be so taken.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: And by this Vallain La Mure too! for now I know 'Tis hee, tho' misery and Age disguise me from him. But to relieve us‚Äîtake this advise, Son, when we are landed yonder, instead of searching for the Fugitive Woman, throw thy self on the mercy of the Protectress; there's more pity to be expected from them, than from this Barb'rous Wretch.

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.p:
Well counsell'd, Sir‚ÄîI'le do't‚Äîand hope good Heaven
will take compassion on us.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: We are undone else.

div.head: SCENE, The Grotto.
div.stage: Enter Hippolita, Julietta, Ariadne, Menalippe, Clita.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Come, my dear, the Song, the Song! methinks I'm so merry o'th' suddain!

lg.l: CInthia, with an awful Power,
O're all Hearts extends her sway:
Did the Eastern Natives know her,
They'd less prize the God of Day.
On her Brow Night shady lyes,
Whilst Morning Breaks from her fair Eyes.
When she Dances, all the Graces
Charming motion treat your Eyes;
When she sings, she doubly blesses,
With her skill, and Angels Voice.
Musicks soul in Airs sublime,
Whilst every Heart still beats the time.
When she smiles, you may discover
Golden Coasts, and wealthy Bliss;
But her Frowns throw back each Lover‚ñ™
To Cold Green-land, where we freeze.
Men may see the Glittering Shore,
But ne're deserve, to reach the Ore.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: This is the happiest Day that ever blest our Life. Some of the men are landed already.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Where, where! did you see 'em, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Through the West-Gate of the Garden that looks towards the Sea. Well, I swear there's one of 'em so pretty a fellow, that I could not forbear Oagling him for my Heart.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: You mad Creature, you: And yet he may be a Monster under his Clothes, for ought you know.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: If he were: He is not the first Monster a Woman has bin fond of, I hope. I knew one so fond of a Monkey once, she desir'd to be marry'd to't.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: Why really the Masculine Creature comes so near the Nature of Humanity, that really one would wonder: But did she desire to wed the Creature!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: But, Sister, prithee are they all young Men: Can'st thou tell? For you know Age will but trouble us; Their Imperfections are not to be reform'd: And your man, when he comes to be old, is good for little or nothing.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Why, troth, I think these are a mixt Party, some young, some old; some weak, and some strong; some that look briskly, as if they had Wit; and others Clownishly, as if they might be made Fools.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Venus direct me to one of them. I long to make a Fool of a Man strangely.

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: Ay, that's a general longing amongst us: For I never heard yet, that a woman was very desirous that a man should get the upper-hand of her.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Then she's a Fool. For my part, Ple give a Man the upper hand of me, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: Alas! she's too young to understand good Decorum. To use a good Decorum is a wonderful thing: And wonderful things are beyond thy knowledge, Child. The Girl is very ignorant, really.

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: Why then I desire to be instructed really. 'Tis strange you'l allow no one to speak of a man, but your self.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: 'Tis likely my Abilities are more‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: Your Abilities‚Äî

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: Alas! thou art a young, raw, crude insipid thing, really.

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: And you are a stale, musty, undesirable thing, really; nay, to vex you throughly, a thing of five and forty.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: How! five and forty‚Äîlet me come to her. Really the Creature provokes me now.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: How now Malapert! how dare you mention any ones age?

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: I five and forty! you Squab-Duckling?

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: Yes, that you are, and more; and your Desires lye so hid in the Ashes of your age; that 'tis impossible to kindle ye.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: But if I were as she, I'd kindle ye‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: What, are you coming in with your Abilities too?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I'le tell you instantly.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Hold, hold‚Äîpray let us not enter into Battel upon the Point; but leave it to the Men rather, who by this time are coming to receive Audience: But come, enough of this dear Sister; we shall have our hands full, I warrant you‚Äî

div.stage: Enter Marine, Du Pier, Boldsprite, Aminta, Franvil, Frugal, Hazard, and Surgeon.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: A Common-Wealth of Women, say you, Captain?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Most certain! all Women; and such as share the Vanity and Ambition of the Sex, secure and unconfin'd.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What will become of us now? All Women! what! ne're a Man amongst 'em, to get 'em Children; and do such Drudgery.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not one, Sir.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Sure they'l be good to me, for Sexes sake?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: And have we then, like Flounders, leapt out of the Frying-Pan into the Fire: Fled from a Female Fiend or two at home, to be plagu'd here with a whole Nation of Devils?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: For my part I expect to be unman'd within these two days, so prefer'd as a Chamber-maid to one of 'em, and daily employ'd in the most Heroick Exercises of washing and starching.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Washing and starching! why, thou speak'st of Honourable Employments. Come, shall I give thee a taste of thy true Office? Thou wilt be prefer'd to be Gentleman-Usher in ordinary to her Ladiships Lap-Dog.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Nay, hear it out, Man: And dayly be Commanded to exercise thy patience in holding him out upon natural Necessities.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Oh! Zooks, I'le be hang'd first.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: And for thy part, thou wilt [To Frug. be doom'd three times a week to pair her Nails, and Cut her Corns; and without any hopes of going further, upon the forfeiture of a Limb, for every such adventure.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Oh insupportable! the Devil shall have her first.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p:
And if thou fail'st in the least punctilio of Duty, then
expect the lash, for thou wilt be jerk'd unmercifully. Nay they will do it only to breathe upon thee; and scourge thee every Morning to keep themselves in wind.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Oh, dear Lieutenant, not a word more, unless you would see me give up the Ghost before you. He has given me the griping of the Guts with the thought on't already.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, come, take Courage; they will be kinder.
And hark! the Musick sounds, they are coming,
Be sure you all stand ready, and look boldy;
And with your best Behaviour make addresses.
Our Lives and Liberties depend upon their pities,
And Death waits on their Anger.

div.stage: Enter Roselia, Clarinda, Menallippe, Clita, Hippollita, Julietta, Ariadne and Guards.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Oh, the Pox take 'em, how imperiously they look?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Sure they are Furies!

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Let them be Devils, they are Devils of Flesh and Blood. And after so long a Lent, to me they are Angels.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! are these the Jewels you run mad for? These Jack-a-Lents! these shrivel'd poor stufft Eel-skins!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pox on her! what does she call us Eel-skins?

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: What can you see amongst these signs of Men, that can oblige from you a gentle look?

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Signs of Men! very fine‚Äî

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: The Devil take 'em, they fright me plaguily!

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: We see with our own Eyes, Madam. Besides Age makes your Highness look through the wrong end of the perspective.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: Can nothing perswade you to love your selves; and place your happiness in Cold and Chaste Embraces of each other?‚Äîalas! my Child: Thou know'st not what man is.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No‚Äîbut I desire to know, that's the Point.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: And when thou do'st; how soon wilt thou repent?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I know not: but I fancy I should not a great while.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: But they are starv'd!

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: No matter, we'll feed 'em up; we'll cram 'em as we do Chickens, but we'll fatten 'em really.

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: Besides, Madam, we had your grant to have 'em as they were.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: D'ee see the Woman, Madam?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
I have view'd her long‚ÄîI swear, 'tis a sweet Creature!
And to my self I do appear deform'd, when I consider her. And yet she is the Stranger's Sister! why then should I fear? She cannot be my Rival.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: When you repent
That you refus'd my Council; may that add
To your afflictions, that you were so forward
To leap into the Gulph of your misfortunes.
But have your wishes‚ÄîI will keep my promise.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: I am instructed: But take heed, dear Friend, you prove not false; my life you know depends on't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou art thy own assurance.
And should'st so well discern thy own perfections,
No doubt should reach thee: Not a word more.
You know me.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: They make towards us: I am damnably afraid of that Old Woman, her Blood is Curdled: Pox on her, she has no Devil in her.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: That you are poor and miserable Wretches,
My Eyes inform me: That, without our Succours,
Hope cannot flatter you to dream of safety,
The present Case you are in can resolve you;
That to be merciful, is to draw near
The Heavenly Essence. Whether you will be
Thankful, I do not question, nor demand
What Countrey bred you, what names, what manners.
To us it is sufficient we relieve
Such as are miserable: And I command you,
As we are not ambitious to know
Farther of you, that you, on pain of Death,
Presume not to enquire, what we are,
Or whence deriv'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In all things, we obey you.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: You speak as becomes you.
First then, and willingly, deliver up
Those Weapons we could force from you.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: How! Have I bid defiance to the rage of Fire and Water, and held the Devil at staves end so often, to be baffled at last by an old Weather-beaten Fire-ship?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We lay 'em down most gladly at your feet.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: I have had a Combat with many a bold Wench,
But never was disarm'd before.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Well‚ÄîI do hope to live to see her turn'd into a Gibb-Cat, and mewing upon the top of the House for all this.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Hark you! have yon a mind to be hang'd, Scoundrel, ha?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
No great Stomach to't, Lieutenant: I had rather go to
‚Ä¢ upper, for my part.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Mum then‚Äînot a word more, for your life.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: And now hear Comfort.
Your wants shall be supply'd: And tho' it be
A debt, Women may challenge to be sued to;
Especially, from those we may Command;
We give you up that Power. And therefore
Freely each make his Choice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Can this be true, Sirs! sure we dream?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: 'Tis certainly true, and we are the happiest Rogues‚Äî

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: O rare old Woman, gad sa' me! why, who would have thought this of her?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Ay, who indeed? But come, let's mind our Business.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then here I fix.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.l: Nay, hold‚Äîshe's mine, I chose her first.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.l: And this mine! ah, this little Rogue, will lye so snug.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: And this mine: There's nothing like Womans-flesh after a long Lent‚Äîdear Fubs, I make bold.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Yours, Rascals, yours! what, before my Captain here,
And I am serv'd? hah! Stand off, Varlets;
Touch 'em not, on your peril: Harkee Monsieur Wardrobe,
You are not giving order to a Taylor
For the fashion of a new suit now?
Nor are you in your Ware-house, Mr. Cit.
Stand back, and give your betters place; we are Soldiers.
And grumble not, for if you do, as I love meat,
I will so swinge the salt Itch out of you‚Äî
Away, I say. And now Captain, Master, and the rest
Of us, that are Brothers, and good Fellows, we have bin
Too late by the Ears, and yet smart for our Follies.
To end therefore all future Emulation,
If you please to trust to my Election, you shall say
I am not partial to my self. And doubt not,
I'll give you all Content.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Agreed; with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.l: Ay, ay; agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.l: Ay, ay; agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Then do but observe how learned and discreetly
I will proceed; and as a skilful Doctor,
In all the quirks belonging to the matter,
Read over your Complexions‚Äîfor you, Captain,
Being first in place, and therefore first to be serv'd,

I give my Judgment thus: For your aspect, you are much inclin'd to melancholly, and that tells me that sullen Saturn
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
predominance at your Nativity; a malignant Planet,
And if not qualify'd by a sweet Conjunction,
A soft and sanguine Girl, born under Venus,
It may prove fatal: Therefore to your arms
I give this blooming Creature.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: As I could wish: Till now I ne're was happy.

sp.speaker: Aminta.
sp.p: Nor I accurs'd!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A curse of that Lieutenant; I hope I shall have the heart to cut his Throat, one time or other.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Master, you are old, and may want spurring up:
Therefore to oblige you, here's a Bradamanta,
Young, wanton as the Roe, and brisk, and sound Boy.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: A weak old Man allotted to my Share!
I'le have none of him.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Thou would'st have two‚Äînay, I think twenty;
But fear not, sweet-heart; tho' he be old, he's tough;
He'll never flinch for't.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: A very pleasant fellow that.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Here's a fair Heard of Does methinks before me,
And now for a Barren one.
For tho' I am Arts-Master of the Science,
I do not love to Father Children: Like the Grand
Signior then, thus I walk in my Seraglio;
And view 'em as I pass: Then draw I forth my Handkerchief;
And having made my choice: I thus bestow it.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: On me, why thou art not mad?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: No, faith‚ÄîI have onely a fit of Love upon me, or so:
And now my Choice is made‚Äîfall on ye hungry Rascals.‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: He's merry. Oh my heart! now, dear Marine, remember your Vows.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hush, no more of that, if you love me; we are observ'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Do but see what a strong Contention there is, betwixt my
Mothers mirth and anger.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Nay, nay, no Coyness, Madam: Be Mistress of your word,
For I am resolute, and must, and will enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Be advis'd, Fool: I am old.
What canst thou e're expect from one that's fifty?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Never talk on't; the older the better:
For your youthful stomachs are still Craving.
Ay, laugh on, laugh on: Good Gentlemen, do:
I shall make holyday, and sleep.
When 'tis ten to one your Hearts ake.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: A strange mad fellow this!
Well, Sir, I'le give you hearing. And as I like
Your wooing and discourse‚Äîbut I must tell you, Sir,
We rich Widows, look for great Sums in present;
Or assurances of Ample Jointures.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Sums in present‚Äîwith all my heart‚ÄîI'le present
Ye a Jewel worth 500 pieces immediately.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Ay, if thou can'st but do that now!

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Can do it‚Äîwhy, what is't a young brisk able Fellow cannot do? Harkee, Captain, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What say'st thou?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Why, faith, that to wooe a Widow with empty hands,
Is no good Heraldry; therefore let's to the Gold,
And share it equally, 'twill speak for us,
More than a thousand Complements or Cringes.
Besides, 'twill beget us respect,
And if ever Fortune befriend us with a Ship,
Largely supply us with provision.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well advis'd: Defer it not: bring in the Trunks there.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Are you all contented?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: All, all.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: This Fellow talks Mountains.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Nay, Madam, now your grief is unseasonable.
Indeed I love you as my Sister. And you
Shall find it‚ÄîI love your Brother two.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Oh my Cruel Fortune‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: See here, the Idol of the Lapidary.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: To get these Pearls, the slavish Negro
Dives to the bottom of the Sea. And thus
I make good my promise.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.l: And here's Gold, for which the Industrious
Merchant touches at either Pole‚Äî

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Hah‚ÄîOh ye immortal Powers!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I'le give my Mistress this Jewel: then draw her into play, top false Dice upon her, and rook her on't agen.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Here's the never-failing purchase of Lordships and Honours.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.l: For which the Sailer Scorns tempestuous winds,
And spits defiance in the Sea.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Ay, she's surpris'd, Boys‚Äî
I knew this would take her strangely.
What says my reverend illustrious Mistress,
Look I not lovely now?

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Uglier than Hell‚ÄîOh my Stars!
Be now for ever blest, that thus have brought
To my revenge these Robbers: Take your Javelins all;
And nail these Monsters to the Earth.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: What's that, are we Monsters agen, already?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Hey day‚Äîwhat a plague's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Oh Daughter!
And you Companions with me in all fortunes,
Look on this Treasure; and these Jewels.
These were my own, I know 'em perfectly:
With these my dear Sebastian put to Sea.
And, doubtless, these the Villains, these the Pyrates,
That not alone depriv'd him of this Treasure,
But took his life.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Harkee, Lieutenant, you see this does take her strangely.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Confound your Politiques: now we are ten times worse than ever.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Peace, ye Curs you: Do I live to be the Subject of your mouldy jests?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What Cruel Fate pursues us! this Chance is past redressing.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: I am well enough serv'd, that must be offering Jointures,
Jewels, and precious things; more than I brought with me.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Now strike all; revenge, revenge.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Hear me, Dear Mother!
And when the greatest Cruelty is justice,
Do not shew mercy. Death to these starv'd Wretches
Is a Reward, not a Punishment: Let 'em live
To know the full weight of your displeasure,
And that they may have sense to feel the Torments
They have deserv'd: Allow 'em some small time.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: 'Tis well Counsell'd. Be it so.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: For the Captain here, I'le be his Jaylour;
I'le fetter him to purpose.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Gracious Madam‚Äîhear us but speak.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Insolent Traytors! would you speak! Away with them.
Chain 'em in Prisons: Vengeance, tho' slow pac'd,
At last o'retakes the Guilty. And the rage
Of the incensed Powers, still falls most sure
On Villains, when they think they're most secure.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: SInce Love the noblest passion of our Souls,
With sacred influence, was ordain'd by Heaven;
To refine us from the Dross of dull mortality,
Why is't a fault in me? It is not, must not.
I am sure I was Created to love on;
And be I hope belov'd‚ÄîOh this dear Stranger,
Can he be guilty of such Villanies? No, 'tis
Impossible! my Mother wrongs him sure!
Here comes his Sister‚Äîshe must be my
Agent‚ÄîI have her in my Power.
And she must serve me.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Can any misery be compar'd to mine?
Or any love have so severe a Fortune?
Oh, Marine! Where art thou now, my life,
My better part?
Or what's this senseless frame, without thee!
Hah, the Protectresses Daughter! your pardon,
Madam; I fear I am to blame.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Not at all. Come hither, be not frighted,
And think not you steal this Liberty: For
I give it you.
Your tender years, and Innocence, assure me
You had no share in the wrongs these men did us:
Your Brother was mis-led sure.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: He mis-led, Madam!
Alas! he's innocent of all he's tax'd with:
But I Perhaps know something of your Story.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How! you know something?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Yes, Madam, there's something in your late relation,
So like my own misfortunes; that my heart
Has ever since bin rack'd with hopes and doubts.
I think you said Don Sebastian was your Father.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Most certainly! a noble Portugal! undone by Pyrates.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Such a Sebastian was my Father too, like him,
A Portugal, and like him undone! Oh! speak on,
For my mind gives me, I can make some great Discovery.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: It's impossible it shou'd relate to us. But however,
Some other time I'le give you hearing; now I
Have other Business, you say your Brother is entirely innocent.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: He is; I am sure he is: For he's a Man
Grounded in so much Virtue, and so noble:
No baseness e're could shelter in his heart.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I must believe it: and now share my Soul,
With it its dearest secret‚ÄîI love him.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Love him, Madam!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Yes, and never shall have peace, till I am His wife.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Oh Heavens‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ha! the meaning of that sigh, does the news Displease you?

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: No Madam: 'Twas onely the effects of my surprize.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Take care, how you abuse me. I have trusted you with more than my life, my first Love: Therefore use me well. And dearest Sister: For so I'le call you ever. And methinks we should be Sisters, Natural Sisters: Yet, if you were, I could not love you more; befriend me in this Business.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: To my power, Madam. Yet tho' he has some Virtue,
He has faults too! nor can deserve your Love,
For you will find him dangerous, fickle, proud:
Soon glutted with your love, and soon forgetful;
I could say more‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Do not, lest I suspect you.
But use your utmost art to win him for me.
(For I perceive you have an interest in him.)
Or failing, lose your self, and me for ever:
I have given him liberty to walk in the Grove
By the Sea-shore. And where to night you'l find him,
Moaning his Fortune; there alone accost him.
Be but successful, and by this I swear,
I'le always love, and ever keep thee here.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Discovers Franvile washing in a Tub, Hazard sowing, and Surgeon spinning, with Waiters looking over them with Whips.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: AH the Devil take the Captain, that brought us to this Cursed Place. Why, rowing at the Gallies is better by half than this slavery.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ay, if I had bin rul'd by my poor Spouse at home,
I had never come to this; well, dear Peggy,
I find the loss of thee now?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Come, come; few know the goodness of Wives, till they want 'em. Ah would I were at home, I'd ne're throw a main agen, but live sober, and sing Psalms‚Äîprithee Surgeon thred this Needle for me?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Alas, I cannot see, Man! I have made my self blind with weeping.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Come, come, mind your business.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Oh that ever I should come to this‚Äîlittle did I think, when I put to Sea, to fall into the hands of these Petticoat-whipsters! Oh, gads bud‚ÄîI have spun a fair thread.

div.stage: Enter D. Pier, with a Bottle of Wine, Boldsprite‚ÄîHippollita, Menalippe.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Nay, Faith you do well to air us, Ladies, we should grow musty else. But prithee, my dear Penthisilea, whence comes this kindness‚Äî'Tis excellent Wine, Faith.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis the favour of the Protectress Daughter;
I wish you deserve it.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: Nay, the best way to make us deserve it,
Is to fill our bellies, that's the truth on't.
Here, Master.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Come, skink away Boy.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: How, the Lieutenant at liberty! and drinking Wine too! whilst we are famishing here. Choak him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I thought they would free him‚Äîah these Women love a strong Fellow strangely.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Madam, my service t'ee‚Äîhere's a health‚Äîlet me see‚Äîhere's a health‚Äîto your merry thought.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Now their hearts are steept in Wine, and their bones at rest. They can talk a little.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Prithee do not slander our bones‚Äîbut let 'em be quiet, they have bin our Servants thus long, and had their share of Pains and Recreations; and to affront 'em now, gad is fowl play.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Well, Fools may talk of Mythridate, Cordials, Elixers; but from my Cradle this was my only Physick‚Äîwhy, here's a Colour now! what Lady's Cheek, tho' Cerus'd and Virmillion'd like a picture, comes near it? Here's your Complexion for you! O my dear, faith I love thee with passion.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: There's Fruits, and Confections within too, Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: A pox, Boys meat‚ÄîI am past it, here's strong food for Men. Nectar, old Lad. Mistress of Merry-hearts, once more I am bold with you.

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: Take heed man‚Äîprithee be temperate: [Drinks. Let's be sober.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Temperate! why, how now Tarr! hast thou liv'd at Sea so long, where to be sober, whil'st we have Wine aboard, is Capital Treason, and dost thou preach Temperance, and Sobriety?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: See, the rest of your Companions are at their Duty.
What think you now, are you not happy in us?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Hang him, he has found us out; now shall we be jeer'd to Death.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: And what think you of changing places with one of these now‚Äîhah‚Äî

sp.speaker: Bolds.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd first.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha‚Äîwhy, how now Monsieur Wardrobe, what in the Sudds? Well, scoure the Shifts clean, d'ee hear! Sirrah‚ÄîOr your Patroness will swinge you. Look, Master, here's another of 'em at his Exercise.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Prithee, dear Lieutenant, leave Joking; and give us a sup of the Bottle. We are almost starv'd.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: What, my honest Partner, and Companion in starving, Ned Glister-pipe too! Harkee; Thou hast skill in Phlebotomy. Let the Ladies blood. Cool 'em, Cool 'em; d'ee hear? 'Tis a better Employment; and leave spinning, you Fool, leave spinning.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Leave spinning! Ay, would I could i'faith.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: One gulph, dear Lieutenant; but one gulph.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Well said, honest In and In‚ÄîCome 7 or 11? Sirrah, I set you this Bottle.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh that this damn'd Epicure, should have the pleasure of being drunk, and we ready to Choak.

div.stage: Enter Frugal, with a Monkey in's arms, follow'd by Julietta, who is fondling it.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Oh my Jewel, my pretty Dear Jewel.
Sirrah take him up agen: what do you grow lazy?

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.l: Oh the Devil; what a Jewel's here! Insupportable! Zooks,
I'le hang my self. I will never lead this life.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: What's here, my Baboon Merchant too! ha, ha, ha; not to hinder your business, Friend; one word with you‚Äîwhat think you now,
sp.l: Am not I a Conjurer?

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.l: A Devil, I think.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Sirrah‚ÄîCarry the dear Creature to the River side, and let him drink‚Äîdo't quickly‚Äîmust I spur you on, you dull Drone‚Äî

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: The dear Creature! a pox on it's Dearness‚Äîgad I'le hang my self to night‚ÄîBut I'le first be reveng'd on her‚Äîfor I'le hang up her Monster too‚ÄîI am resolv'd on that‚Äî

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Well, honest Towzer‚Äîfarewell to thee.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: Come, let's be gone‚ÄîI see Clarinda coming yonder.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Go march, Sir, march. Nay, without reply, as you expect to be oblig'd hereafter.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.l: One word to my Friends first, and then I am for you.
Well, Gentlemen, why don't you Joke now?
What not one jeer all this while‚Äîhah‚Äîharkee, Friends.
sp.p: Look to 'em, d'ee hear! and give 'em due Correction. They'l never mind their Business else. I know 'em to a hair. Ha, ha, ha‚Äî

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Is there no remedy? Must the Captain, and this Devil of a Lieutenant, perpetually plague us? And we not revenge it.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Well thought on, faith: I have found one way to do it, and home too.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Yonder comes the Protectresses Daughter: VVho, I am certain, loves the Captain. And he has told her, this Lady that came with him, is his Sister. Now the only way to be reveng'd on 'em all, and procure our Liberty, is to‚Äî

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Inform her the contrary.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Let's do't instantly, here she comes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Bless thy Divine Beauty.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Mirrour of sweetness, vouchsafe one word, we beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Poor flattery! what would you have, ye wretches?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We can discover something that concerns you‚Äî

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Something about the Captain.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ha. The Captain!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Promise us but our Liberty, and a little meat, and you shall know all.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Know all! how they make me tremble! what shall I know? Speak, and if it merits favour, you shall have it.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: This little Gentlewoman that's with the Captain‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Well‚Äîwhat of her‚Äîhis Sister, you mean.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Sister‚Äîha, alas! you are deceiv'd in her!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Deceiv'd in her.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: She is no Sister.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No Sister‚Äîwhat is she then? speak quickly! Oh my heart.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: She is his‚Äî

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Peace: Let me speak‚Äîwhy, faith, sweet Lady, she is as a Man would say his‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: VVhat?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: His Mistress‚Äîor so. That's the plain truth on't.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: They say, she is Virtuous‚Äîbut she has bin his Cabin-Mate this six Months, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: His Cabin-mate too‚Äîoh this slye Serpent: Be sure you do not lie to me.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: If I do‚Äîhang me empty‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No‚Äîyou shall be fed‚Äîbut with such food as you have given me, new misery‚Äîaway with 'em to Prison‚Äîspeak not a word‚Äîbegon. Oh I could rage and Curse, and kill now. Kill him, her, any thing in my revenge; which they shall feel, and instantly. And now brave Mother, follow thy noble Anger: And I'le help thee.

div.stage: Enter Hippolita, Julietta, Ariadne, Menalippe, Clita.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What storm is coming now? What must we lose the Men agen?

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: I'le lose my life first‚ÄîI assure you, I like my Man extreamly.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: The Rogues are plaguy unfortunate. I am afraid we shall have but an unlucky breed from 'em.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: Yes really, the fellows behave themselves with diligence enough.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.l: What betwixt fear, and love, they do their Duty:
But for my part, I begin to distate the mercinary Rogues.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: They say they are Gentlemen: But they prove Mungrels.

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: Pray do not rail at the men: I'le assure you, mine proves admirably.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: How do thine suffer; Iuliet?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Faith, like Boys: They are fearful in all Fortunes‚Äîwhen I smile, thay kneel, and beg to have that Face Continued‚ÄîAnd like poor Dogs, adore the ground I go on; when I frown, they hang their Tails, like fearful Sheep-hounds‚Äîshew 'em a Crust of bread, they'l Saint me presently.
sp.l: Frisk up and down, and skip about like Apes;
And for a drop of Wine, be whipt like Hackney's.
I can saddle 'em, ride 'em‚Äîdo what I will with 'em.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: Ridiculous Wretches: Have they names like Christians.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Oh, very fair names, and brag of mighty Kindred too. They offer very handsomely. But that I am a Fool, and dare not venture too much; they are sound too, o'my Conscience, or very near upon't.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: These are poor, base, Creatures.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Pax on 'em‚Äî'tis that makes me hate 'em: If they were, or would be manly in their sufferings, perhaps one might strain a point or two.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Mine, I assure you, were not cast in such base Mould‚ÄîAfflictions, Tortures, are Names, and Natures of delight to my Men. They sleep soundly, and seldome troublesome, unless, 'tis when they dream of Fights and Tempests‚ÄîAnd then they roar, and whistle for Bottles of Wine. And sometimes down they'l throw me‚Äîand in that rage, for they are violent fellows, they play such Freaks‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, the Rogues will fumble one strangely.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: If they have meat, they thank me; if none, they heartily desire they may be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Ariad.
sp.p: Come, come; let's all go to the Protectress, and intercede for 'em.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: For my part really, I'le mutiny if I have not mine freed to night.

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: And I mine‚Äîfor I assure you, he's a Man every inch of him.

div.stage: Enter La Mure, Bourchier, Sebastian, Nicusa, and Sailers, with a dark Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: This Grove, Sir, belongs to the Protectresses Palace. And the Lights, that we saw just at our Entrance, I suppose belong to her.

sp.speaker: La Mur.
sp.p: Begar you had best supposa right. And lead us right too. If I no find this damn'd Woman, I shall find your head: Morbleu I will hang you, dat is in plain Term.

sp.speaker: Bour.
sp.p: Hush, Sir‚Äîand pray let us hide our selves behind these Bushes. For, if my Eyes are perfect; I see a Man coming down the walk.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Fly Son to the Protectress, this is the Minute, or we are lost. Throw thy self at her feet, and discover us‚ÄîI'd rather be at her mercy, and in Slavery, than live to be thus us'd by this horrid Villain; away‚Äîthat's the Palace just before thee.

sp.speaker: Bour.
sp.p: I could discern him plainly‚ÄîI am certain, 'twas a man‚Äîha, and yonder I think he comes.

sp.speaker: Amint. Marine!
sp.p: my Love, where art thou?

sp.speaker: La Mur.
sp.p: Jerne, is not that she?

sp.speaker: Bourch.
sp.p: It is, Sir‚ÄîI heard her Voice.

sp.speaker: La Mur.
sp.p: Stand close, make no noise.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: How well this darkness suits my melancholly? Who's there?

sp.speaker: Marine!
sp.p: but who else can it be? No other Man's at liberty in the Island. Oh my best life: I have the saddest news to tell thee: But come, let us go farther off, to secure us from being over-heard.

sp.speaker: La Mure.
sp.p: Ay begar, you sal be secura presantly! I will secure you‚Äî

sp.speaker: Bour.
sp.p: He has carry'd her off; come, let's follow.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: I must obey you, Sir! Cruel Fortune! no news of my Son yet!

div.stage: Enter Roselia, Clarinda, Nicusa, Menallippe, Clita, Guards.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: Search round the Grove‚ÄîAnd all you find bring hither, if they resist, or, seem unwilling, force 'em‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Force Marine hither too, and the sly Witch, his pretended Sister.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: Stranger, thou hast told me wonders, which if true, as by my beating heart I have some hopes, this day will be the happiest of my life‚ÄîYou say your Name's Nicusa?

sp.speaker: Nicus.
Rosel.
sp.p: More wonders still, for by that name they still'd the Villain that was Author of our Misery.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Believe him not, Madam; he is a Man: And men have the Curst trick of lying from their Cradles.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: I hope he does not. And now methinks there are some features in his face‚ÄîI am acquainted with‚Äîwhat was your Mother's name?

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.p: Roselia.

sp.speaker: Roselia.
sp.p: Oh Heaven!

sp.speaker: Nicus.
sp.p: One, whom tho' I can hardly remember, yet if I may presume to speak my thoughts, had some features just like yours‚ÄîBut here comes one will satisfie you fully.

div.stage: Enter Sebastian, Marine, La Mure, Aminta, Bourchier, guarded‚ñ™

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: So much of joy crowds fast into my heart,
There is not room for utterance: Oh, speak Sir, speak!
And if you are Sebastian; speak it boldly:
And give me joy as great, as is my wonder:
For sure you much resemble that dear Man‚Äî
Which if you prove‚Äîlook up, and see Roselia,
Your Roselia.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: 'Tis so, by all that's sacred. Thou art mine indeed.
For sure as thou art Roselia, I am Sebastian.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Oh my dear Lord!

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Propitious Stars, I thank you.
And Fortune! now thou hast rewarded me
For all past miseries.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Rise Son. And now, my Dear Sebastian!
Look on Clarinda here; this is thy Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Thou beauteous Spring, and Fountain of my joys, receive my Blessing‚ÄîBut Aminta, my lost Aminta‚Äîwere she but here too, then my joys were perfect.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Who calls Aminta‚Äîhere I am, and come to make a third in this strange meeting.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: Miracle, on Miracle!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This Adventure would make a Theam for an Excellent History ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: I am Aminta, and, as I was inform'd by my Nurse, am Daughter to Sebastian and Roselia. More of the business, that French Pyrate there, whom Heaven has strangely thrown upon this Island, can soon inform you‚Äî

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: By all that's good‚Äî'Tis he! that Villain, La Mure; I know him.

sp.speaker: Bour.
sp.p: So‚Äîwe are in a hopeful condition.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Suspend your wonder, Madam‚Äî'Tis the same, that Execrable Robber, that caus'd our separation.

sp.speaker: La Mure.
sp.p: I was saying just now, I vud hang him, Morbleu, now I fear he will hanga me! Oh damn'd Whore, Zh ‚Ä¢ lt, Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Speak, abhor'd Villain! And if thou can'st discover any thing to save thy life, do it quickly.

sp.speaker: La Mure.
sp.p: The Diable take you all. Dat is all I vill discover, vor, vrom dis moment, me vil no open my Lips.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: Let him be rack'd; Slave, we'll make you confess.

sp.speaker: Bourch.
sp.l: Hold, Madam!
I, as his Companion, can inform you
In any thing you demand.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: What is this Lady here?

sp.speaker: Bourc.
sp.l: She is you ‚Ä¢ Daughter, and her name, Aminta!
The Infant that La Mure carry'd away with him,
When he left you alone upon this Island,
sp.p: She has bin bred in England, from whence to avoid his Love, she lately fled away with this young Gentleman, and afterwards wrackt upon that Island, where you found 'em.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: The rest I can make out: upon that very Island,
Seeking for shelter from this Insolent Robber:
I landed with my Son, and some Negro-Slaves,
That set upon me for my treasure, and after in
sp.p: The fray ruin'd themselves. There for the space of sixteen tedious Years, we liv'd oppress'd with all the miseries humanity could suffer, till Heaven grown weary of afflicting us, by the means of this young man, at last reliev'd us. Captain, look in my face, do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not I, Sir; nor can I ever call to mind, that I, till, now have seen you.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: I shall refresh your Memory:
Have you forgot two wretched Portugals?
That, whilst you were mutining for the Gold
They shew'd you‚ÄîCut the Cable, got your
Ship away, and left you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That trick of Fortune, Sir, I have reason to remember.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Those famish'd Portugals, were my self and Son‚Äîbut being at Sea, we were afterwards retaken by La Mure, and describing your company, and this young Virgin, who now I'le call my Daughter; whom it seems he came in search of; we were brought back, where now we live to make you some amends for all past ills. But where are all your Comrades?

sp.speaker: Rosel
sp.l: Go, set 'em all at liberty‚Äîand bring 'em hither:
The Case is clear now, how they got that Treasure:
And, dear Aminta! let me hold thee fast,
Here to my heart‚Äîwhilst tears Express my joy,
For this most strange unlook'd for change of Fortune.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Oh Mother! what a happy hour is this! How blest! how full of rapture! And as the chief Author of all our present Happiness, receive this noble Gentleman. No Brother now, but my betrothed Husband.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: Sir, for your ill usage, happening thro' our Errors, let this attone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A gift Heaven cannot mend.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: Which thus I ratifie‚ÄîCaptain, she's thine‚Äî

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.l: Now, dearest Sister, I can truly call you so!
Forgive the small offence done to your Love;
Oh pardon it,‚ÄîI conjure you by your Virtue.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I do with all my heart. And from this moment banish all fond desires.

div.stage: Enter Du Pier, Franvil, Frugal with a rope about their necks. Hazard, Boldsprite, Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Madam, tho' Fortune willing to oblige me,
And make amends for many days of sorrows,
Gives me your Sister: And in her all happiness:
Yet in the midst af all this Crowd of joy,
My grateful heart does still remember you;
And thankfully acknowledge all your favours.

sp.speaker: Menal.
sp.p: So, so! I like this very well‚Äînow sure some of the men will fall to our share agen.

sp.speaker: Clita.
sp.p: I hope so‚ÄîI am sure there can be no good Conclusion without 'em.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What's to be done with us now, I wonder?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: There are not many new ways of starving, that's my Comfort.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I am to beg your pardon too, and inform you, that you have suffered by a mistake: But now you are free, as if in your own Nation.

sp.speaker: Frug.
sp.p: Gad‚Äî'Twas well you sent as you did: For I was just upon the Swing, the Devil and I had fully agreed upon the matter‚Äîyou may see by my Bridle here. I was just ready for a journey.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: And what say you, my merry mad Lieutenant?
Were you in the same humour?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: I in the same humour! Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p:
Ay, were not you almost ready to Dangle in one of your Garters, for the loss of your Widdow, and the rest of your mighty
Expectations?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: No‚ÄîIf I were, the Dence take me.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: Nor you have not bin concern'd about it?

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: Perhaps I have had the griping of the Guts, A kind of a grumbling humour, or so, to be at you,‚ÄîBut no more‚Äîfor my part, I gave you over for an obstinate Old Woman, and resolv'd to think no more of you.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: Well, Sir, with my self I can do you no justice‚Äîbecause this Gentleman here takes possession of me by a better Title.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: How, a better Title! Faith, methinks a Widdow, and a Woman of your Sense, should think my Title better than his, by twenty years purchase, by your favour, Madam.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: Ay, a Widdow indeed might think so: But know, (Gallant that should have bin) the Fates have so order'd it, that I am now found to be a Wife.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: A Wife!

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: Even so. And to this very Gentleman, that lays such Claim. But to make thee full amends, for the loss of my self‚Äîif this Lady can creep into thy heart‚ÄîTake her, she's thine; she's rich, but a little foppish.

sp.speaker: D. Pier.
sp.p: With all my heart, by this light; she's rich you say‚ÄîI'le marry her, that I may beat her, and make her Loyal.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.p: Come, let's retire, and make a glad relation of our Fortunes: 'Twill add to our content; Oh my Sebastian! I have miracles to tell thee, how I came hither to the Womens Common-Wealth: How chosen Protectress! it is a Tale bears full variety.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.l: And so does mine, which we'll recount at leisure.

sp.speaker: Rosel.
sp.l: Convey those Pyrates straight away to Prison,
Till we consider of their punishment:
For times are alter'd now, so is the Government,
Whilst my Sebastian lives: 'Tis he must rule it.
Prepare a Banquet, and let Musick wait us,
For now we have all the Blessings Fate can give.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I all joys that Crown a happy life,
Possessing my Aminta for my Wife.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: HOW silly 'tis for one, not yet Thirteen,
To hope her first Essay should please you Men:
You cannot taste what such a Creature speaks;
Would she were three years older for your sakes;
Two handfuls taller, a Plump pretty Lass,
I doubt not then my Epilogue would pass.
But, as I am, for your Applause I sue,
Pray spare me for the Good that I may do.
Gallants, I better shall perform e're long,
Despise not a poor thing because she's young.
Twigs may be bent, Trees are too stubborn grown;
And th' Roses Bud is sweet as Roses blown.
In China (as I often have been told)
The Women marry at eleven years old:
Our Play-House is a kind of China too,
And nothing like the Stage to make me grow;
For, tho' not Power, I have the Will to please,
And Will's a mighty help in such a Case.
We on this fruitful Soyl have Women seen,
That in few Months have grown as big agen.
Oh Iemminy! what is the Cause of that?
I wonder what they Eat to grow so Fat?
We young ones know not how that business is;
But for all that we may be allow'd to guess;
And I beginning now to chatter Sence,
Encourag'd, may divert a Twelve-month hence:
And therefore humbly thus I make Address,
Excuse Faults, and accept my Will to please;
But if you fail me, may you nevermore
Kiss Woman under (at the least) fourscore.
